finding: The study identified the RNF213 p.R4810K variant (rs112735431) as significantly associated with intracranial vessel wall enhancement (VWE) in moyamoya disease (MMD). It was shown that this variant had an odds ratio of 2.01, indicating that individuals with this SNP had an increased risk of developing VWE, which is linked to poor prognosis in MMD patients.
title: Clinical and genetic risk factors and long-term outcomes of MRI vessel wall enhancement in moyamoya disease

finding: An association was identified for rs12600879 near TBX21 and OSBPL7, indicating its novel relevance to impulsivity.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: Associated as significant in the female sample for physical activity (PA) and also in the combined sample without heterogeneity.
title: The genetic case for cardiorespiratory fitness as a clinical vital sign and the routine prescription of physical activity in healthcare

finding: The rs4273100 variant located in the 17p11.2 region was associated with the default mode network and showed strong genetic influences related to schizophrenia, MDD, and cognitive ability, reflecting its implications in psychiatric disorders.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The rs12602286 variant in the 17p11.2 region was linked to cognitive ability and education-related traits, particularly affecting the default mode network's frontal cluster, suggesting genetic influences on intellectual performance.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: rs7221651 served as a significant marker on chromosome 17 in the GWAS on European ancestry with a P-value of 3.71 × 10−10. The SNP was also identified in trans-ancestry analysis, showing moderate linkage to rs72631329 (R² = 0.54). Its significance extended to multiple impedance measures including trunk fat mass, indicating potential compositional and functional implications.
title: GWAS of Chronic Dizziness in the Elderly Identifies Significant Loci Implicating MLLT10, BPTF, LINC01225, and ROS1

finding: Found in the trans-ancestry analysis, rs72631329 from chromosome 17 was correlated with rs7221651 (R² = 0.54), marking it as significant for further exploration of chronic dizziness disorders across diverse populations.
title: GWAS of Chronic Dizziness in the Elderly Identifies Significant Loci Implicating MLLT10, BPTF, LINC01225, and ROS1

finding: The study found that the G allele of rs4341 was associated with severe COVID-19 in hypertensive patients, and G-carrier genotypes (which include GG and GC) showed a significant association with higher mortality (<p<0.05) and COVID-19 severity in dyslipidemic (<p<0.05) and type 2 diabetic patients (<p<0.01). This highlighted the G allele's role as a risk factor for adverse COVID-19 outcomes particularly in patients with pre-existing conditions.
title: ACE gene variants rise the risk of severe COVID-19 in patients with hypertension, dyslipidemia or diabetes. A pilot study

finding: Similar to rs4341, the G allele of rs4343 was associated with severe COVID-19 in hypertensive patients. The presence of G-carrier genotypes was also linked to an increased mortality risk (<p<0.05) and greater COVID-19 severity specifically in dyslipidemic (<p<0.05) and type 2 diabetic patients (<p<0.001). This confirmed that rs4343 was also a significant genetic marker for adverse COVID-19 outcomes in high-risk patient populations.
title: ACE gene variants rise the risk of severe COVID-19 in patients with hypertension, dyslipidemia or diabetes. A pilot study

finding: The SNP rs35850753, an intronic variant in the TP53 gene, was associated with an increased risk of multiple invasive cancers (OR=1.35, P=1.2×10^-8) and showed a slightly diminished association when in-situ tumors were included.
title: Unraveling the genetic landscape of susceptibility to multiple primary cancers

finding: This SNP in MAPT showed statistically significant age-dependent effects in relation to lung function.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association study improves resolution of genes, pathways and pleiotropy for lung function and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: Among the rare coding variants, rs148096119 was highlighted as a significant risk variant for episodic memory decline, with a high incidence found in carriers. It was noted to impact a gene related to memory functions.
title: Rare genetic coding variants associated with age-related episodic memory decline implicate distinct memory pathologies in the hippocampus

finding: Associated with concentrations of creatine kinase, a non-specific muscle injury biomarker, and with activated partial thromboplastin time, indicating its role in coagulation through the APOH gene.
title: Using human genetics to understand the causes and consequences of circulating cardiac troponin I in the general population

finding: The SNP rs62637606, a low-frequency missense variant in the PFAS gene, was identified with a posterior probability of causality of 1.0. This indicated its strong association with fetal hemoglobin levels in the context of sickle cell disease.
title: Genomic discovery and functional validation of MRP1 as a novel fetal hemoglobin modulator and potential therapeutic target in sickle cell disease

finding: The SNP rs529633547, an intronic variant in the CTC1 gene, was associated with a posterior probability of causality of 0.80, indicating its relevance to the study of fetal hemoglobin levels in sickle cell disease.
title: Genomic discovery and functional validation of MRP1 as a novel fetal hemoglobin modulator and potential therapeutic target in sickle cell disease

finding: Five deletions and two duplications were identified in moderate LD (R²=0.35-0.67) with rs199515, a tagging SNP of the MAPT H1/H2 haplotype associated with AD.
title: Structural Variation Detection and Association Analysis of Whole-Genome-Sequence Data from 16,905 Alzheimer’s Diseases Sequencing Project Subjects

finding: At the TNFRSF13B locus, the rs34562254 missense variant was fine-mapped by MultiSuSiE with a PIP greater than 0.5, linking it to total protein concentration, as TNFRSF13B is involved in immune response signaling. The variant was not successfully fine-mapped within the Afr47k, Eur47k, or Eur94k datasets due to issues of low GWAS effect size and high levels of linkage disequilibrium.
title: MultiSuSiE improves multi-ancestry fine-mapping in All of Us whole-genome sequencing data

finding: The study established that the inactivating variant of the tumor suppressor XAF1, specifically E134*/Glu134Ter (rs146752602), was associated with an increased risk of developing sarcomas in carriers of the R337H variant. This finding provided significant insights into the interaction between different genetic factors in expressing the full pathogenic potential of Li-Fraumeni syndrome-associated cancers.
title: Fine resolution clustering of TP53 variants into functional classes predicts cancer risks and spectra among germline variant carriers

finding: The SNP rs1641518 near the SHBG gene was part of the novel findings related to PCOS. It exhibited strong effects on hormone levels, particularly showing a nominal association with lower SHBG levels, implicating it in the hormonal dysregulation commonly seen in PCOS.
title: Genomic and proteomic evidence for hormonal and metabolic foundations of polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: At 17q12, rs10908278 in HNF1B was part of the significant PSA findings with compelling association (P = 2.1 x 10^-46), emphasizing its role in genetic predisposition to changes in PSA levels.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The variant rs78378222 in TP53 was identified within the framework of PSA associations, highlighting its role concerning cancer susceptibility.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The SNP rs3760230 was noted for its significant association with PSA, denoting its relevance to genetic studies in prostate cancer.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The variant rs577915581 also had a risk difference (RD) of 1.00, which highlighted its association with Pompe disease, another critical autosomal recessive condition.
title: Deleterious Variants Contribute Minimal Excess Risk in Large-Scale Testing

finding: The germline ERN1 variant rs139229826 was identified in 11% of the Chilean patient cohort, a variant previously unreported in glioblastoma patients. This variant resulted in a L914M substitution in the IRE1α protein. While this substitution was structurally tolerated, it showed potential implications for IRE1's RNase activity due to its proximity to a critical catalytic residue. This finding contributed to understanding ethnic-specific variations in glioblastoma.
title: Characterization of the mutational landscape of high-grade gliomas in a Latin American cohort

finding: The SNP rs2077551, located on chromosome 17, also showed strong associations with brain imaging-derived phenotypes. There were 174 significant associations related to indices of white matter integrity, such as fractional anisotropy and measures in cortical morphology like cortical thickness and area. The findings suggested high IPF genetic risk correlating with increased cortical thinning and specific morphological changes in the brain, indicating a complex relationship between IPF and brain structure.
title: Mapping brain endophenotypes associated with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis genetic risk

finding: The rs73332852 variant at the UBE2G1-SPNS3 locus was found to confer an increased risk for TET2-CH with an OR of 1.50 [1.33-1.69] and a P-value of 6.69 x 10^-11, establishing its significance in the genetic landscape of CH.
title: Comparative analysis of 136,401 Admixed Americans and 419,228 Europeans reveals ancestry-specific genetic determinants of clonal haematopoiesis

finding: The SNP rs12952581 was discovered through the sfFDR framework and was implicated in immune-related processes. It was located 161 kb from the gene ABI3, which has been linked to eosinophil counts. The finding was part of an analysis of obesity-related traits from the UK Biobank and was among the eight additional lead SNPs identified in a rare disease GWAS of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
title: Exploiting pleiotropy to enhance variant discovery with functional false discovery rates

finding: Associated with cervical cancer at p-value 1.2 × 10−9, this SNP was in high LD with GSDMB, which is relevant in cervical cancer invasion.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: This splice acceptor variant in GSDMB was noted for its link to cervical cancer and implicated in the apoptotic processes detrimental to cancer progression.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: This SNP was associated with delayed recall memory performance, featuring a P value of 3.20E-08. It is positioned in an intron of the CEP112 gene, known for its role in centrosome function.
title: Genome-wide association study of Alzheimer’s disease brain imaging biomarkers and neuropsychological phenotypes in the EMIF-AD Multimodal Biomarker Discovery dataset

finding: The SNP rs1808192 was identified as G2-specific, which suggested its role in modifying IgG glycosylation related to the galactose addition process.
title: Mapping of the gene network that regulates glycan clock of ageing

finding: The SNP rs2526377 was noted as G2-specific, demonstrating its significance in the pathway regulating IgG galactosylation.
title: Mapping of the gene network that regulates glycan clock of ageing

finding: The SNP rs34562254 was identified as G1-specific, illustrating its regulation potential in the IgG glycosylation process.
title: Mapping of the gene network that regulates glycan clock of ageing

finding: The SNP rs199516 was also recognized as G0-specific, highlighting its involvement in the regulation of IgG glycosylation, particularly in the initial glycoform.
title: Mapping of the gene network that regulates glycan clock of ageing

finding: The SNP rs121912749 located in SLC4A1 was found to be a non-synonymous SNV (G/A) in the intron region at position 177,093,242 on chromosome 5, leading to an amino acid substitution to G388R. It suggested a connection to cancer progression and tumor cell proliferation.
title: A newly identified pathology of Episodic Angioedema with Hypereosinophilia (Gleich’s Syndrome) revealed by Multi-Omics Analysis

finding: Identified as a novel hypothyroidism locus with gene associations known from mouse studies, indicating its importance in thyroid dysfunction.
title: Uncovering the Shared Genetic Components of Thyroid Disorders and Reproductive Health

finding: The T-allele of rs117143557 correlating with the gene MPRIP showed a very high odds ratio of 17.05 in Japanese athletes for sprint performance, nearly reaching genome-wide significance with a P-value of 7.63E-08, emphasizing its potential as a significant genetic determinant in this cohort.
title: Multi-phase, multi-ethnic GWAS uncovers putative loci in predisposition to human sprint performance, health and disease

finding: The SNP rs4343 was associated with lower systolic blood pressure (SBP) in a study involving the Japanese Biobank, where the A allele was correlated with a -0.26 mmHg reduction in SBP (P = 6.7 x 10^-4). Additionally, this variant was confirmed in a GWAS of individuals with young onset hypertension, where it was strongly linked to ACE activity (P = 3.0 x 10^-25). The findings emphasized its role in influencing blood pressure, which could have implications for colorectal cancer risk evaluations.
title: Genetically-proxied therapeutic inhibition of antihypertensive drug targets and risk of common cancers

finding: The SNP rs9895741, linked to NPLOC4, was related to dark brown hair color with a discordant effect between European (beta=0.104) and Central/South Asian (beta=-0.194) ancestries, revealing significant cross-ancestry genetic variability.
title: Inter-population differences of allele frequency and regulome tagging are associated with the heterogeneity of loci identified by cross-ancestry genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs740516 was significantly associated with LDL levels in a genome-wide association study with a P-value of 7×10−9. Additionally, this SNP was associated with the expression of the gene ABCA6 at a P-value of 3.3×10−5. Although ABCA6 was not found to be causally associated with lipid traits by Mendelian randomization, the association of rs740516 with LDL suggests a significant role of this SNP in lipid metabolism.
title: Functional Characterization of Lipid Regulatory Effects of Three Genes Using Knockout Mouse Models

finding: Found on chromosome 17, rs1269322417 was linked to the genes RPL23 and LASP1. It was a positive original finding associated with AD-by-proxy and suggested differential expression in excitatory and inhibitory neurons.
title: Identification of 16 novel Alzheimer’s disease susceptibility loci using multi-ancestry meta-analyses of clinical Alzheimer’s disease and AD-by-proxy cases from four whole genome sequencing datasets

finding: The SNP rs8070723, associated with the MAPT H1 haplotype, displayed a strong genome-wide significant signal (OR[95%CI]=4.02[3.12–5.19]; p=9.89·10^-27) in the context of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), replicating previous reports.
title: A Novel Susceptibility Locus in NFASC Highlights Oligodendrocytes and Myelination in Progressive Supranuclear Palsy Pathology

finding: The SNP rs242557 was found to map to the MAPT locus and partially represents the PSP risk H1c subhaplotype, showing an odds ratio of 0.72 (95%CI=0.61–0.86; p=2.49·10^-04).
title: A Novel Susceptibility Locus in NFASC Highlights Oligodendrocytes and Myelination in Progressive Supranuclear Palsy Pathology

finding: The SNP rs1122380 was implicated in the MAPT gene's associations and was utilized to adjust the analysis for the H1/H2 haplotype effects in PSP.
title: A Novel Susceptibility Locus in NFASC Highlights Oligodendrocytes and Myelination in Progressive Supranuclear Palsy Pathology

finding: The SNP rs1800547 was used to explore haplotypic associations in the MAPT gene context for PSP risk, showing complete linkage disequilibrium with rs1122380.
title: A Novel Susceptibility Locus in NFASC Highlights Oligodendrocytes and Myelination in Progressive Supranuclear Palsy Pathology

finding: The SNP rs12150603 located in PNMT also showed significant association with unclassified HF in the MVP African American cohort after Bonferroni correction.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The SNP rs1002135 in SMG6 was found to replicate significant associations with heart failure after Bonferroni correction, indicating its relevance in HF genetic research.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The study established that the T allele of <italic>MAPT</italic> rs17649553 was significantly associated with improved verbal memory in Parkinson’s disease (PD) patients. It was reported that T-carriers (CT and TT) maintained verbal memory scores comparable to healthy controls, unlike CC carriers. This association implicated <italic>MAPT</italic> rs17649553 in enhancing the structural topology of gray matter covariance and white matter networks, which correlated with verbal memory performance. Furthermore, mediation analysis indicated that the small-worldness topology in the white matter network mediated the relationship between <italic>MAPT</italic> rs17649553 and verbal memory, suggesting a functional role of this SNP in cognitive function related to PD.
title: Effects of MAPT rs17649553 on Structural Network Integrity and Verbal Memory in Parkinson’s Disease

finding: SNP rs199598395 was associated with iron deficiency anemia and impacted the eligibility for blood donation, highlighting its significant role among blood donors.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: The study identified enrichment of the p.(Arg20Cys) variant (rs200013015) in patients with Primary Antibody Deficiency (PAD), showing a significant odds ratio of 82.12 (CI 9.20-346.93; p=0.0028). This variant was previously classified as a variant of uncertain significance (VUS) in a patient without an immune-related phenotype, but it was later found in patients with antibody deficiency. Despite the statistical significance associated with this variant, it was predicted to have a benign consequence on protein function, warranting further functional studies to explore its effect on B cell function.
title: Clinical exome sequencing data from patients with inborn errors of immunity: cohort level meta-analysis and the benefit of systematic reanalysis

finding: This SNP (RAI1) has been newly associated with coffee consumption, establishing it as a candidate for future research.
title: Habitual Coffee Consumption Increases Risks for Metabolic Diseases: Genome-wide Association Studies and a Phenotype-wide Two Sample Mendelian Randomization Analysis

finding: The variant rs114001633 was identified as a rare missense variant in the SREBF1 gene, which serves as a master regulator for lipogenesis. This variant was associated with higher total cholesterol (TC) levels, with a minor allele frequency of 0.74%. The reported effect size was a beta coefficient of 0.0442 and a p-value of 2.8 x 10^-9, emphasizing its significant contribution to lipid metabolism.
title: Exome wide association study for blood lipids in 1,158,017 individuals from diverse populations

finding: The LRRC37A:rs2732703-G variant showed a significant interaction with APOE ε4, particularly increasing the AD risk in American Admixed ancestry.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: The rs781278654 SNP, corresponding to the c.1483C>T variant in the ATP6V0A1 gene, was identified as one of the compound heterozygous variants associated with early-onset progressive myoclonus epilepsy with ataxia and severe developmental and epileptic encephalopathy. In the study, this variant exhibited an allelic carrier frequency of 0.00001315 in the control population and was predicted to be damaging with a PolyPhen score of 0.99. It was found to co-segregate with the clinical phenotype in an Italian family as well as in another independent individual with overlapping clinical features, although it was absent in a cohort of 200 Italian subjects, indicating its low frequency within this population.
title: Biallelic and de novo variants in ATP6V0A1 cause progressive myoclonus epilepsy and developmental and epileptic encephalopathy

finding: The SNP rs4791503 exhibited a highly significant p-value of 2.96×10−7, with the minor allele (C) frequency being 0.1575 in cases compared to 0.4659 in controls. This resulted in an odds ratio of 0.2144. This SNP is classified as an intron variant within the LINC00670 gene and is positioned near the MYOCD gene, which is crucial for regulating smooth muscle gene expression.
title: Genomic predictors of response to antidepressants in Major depressive disorder (MDD): A GWAS-Based Study on Indian cohort

finding: The rs28712647 variant, positioned upstream of NEURL4 and near ALOX12, was also implicated as having multiple independent signals in the context of VTE.
title: Cross-Ancestry Investigation of Venous Thromboembolism Genomic Predictors

finding: The G allele of the deleterious variant rs1801690 in APOH was associated with reduced TSH levels. It also indicated an increased risk of hyperthyroidism, congenital anomalies of endocrine glands, and thyrotoxicosis, alongside other metabolic parameters like increased AST and ALT levels.
title: Genome-wide association study of thyroid-stimulating hormone highlights new genes, pathways and associations with thyroid disease susceptibility and age-of-onset

finding: This SNP, a missense variant in <italic>GSDMA</italic>, was also identified as a credible candidate associated with DBP concentration, particularly when accounting for the <italic>GC</italic> haplotypes.
title: Genetic correlates of vitamin D-binding protein and 25 hydroxyvitamin D in neonatal dried blood spots

finding: This SNP showed a secondary association with a nominal P=7.71×10-10 at the 17q12 locus, indicating a novel association.
title: Genome-wide trans-ethnic meta-analysis identifies novel susceptibility loci for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia

finding: The SNP rs9913145, located in the TSPOAP1 gene, was linked with executive function. It presented a relatively common frequency and had a low CADD score, indicating it was not strongly deleterious. This study represented a novel finding as this variant had not been previously reported to be associated with cognitive function, suggesting it might tag a haplotype specific to South Asian populations.
title: Region-based analysis with functional annotation identifies genes associated with cognitive function in South Asians from India

finding: The SNP rs4924755 was found to impact the SAT adipocyte expression significantly where risk allele carriers exhibited lower expression levels of SREBF1 and affected 48 downstream genes. Specifically, it influenced multiple adipose genes such as FASN, AGPAT2, and DGAT1, highlighting its important role in abdominal obesity.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The SNP rs7224725 demonstrated significant associations with both the SAT adipocyte expressions and the risk allele carrier status, showing lower expression levels of SREBF1 in risk allele carriers. This SNP was also linked with 23 downstream genes within the context of abdominal obesity.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The SNP rs9944423 was significant in all individuals and particularly in males. Its carrier status was associated with lower expression of SREBF1 and impacted the expression of 23 downstream genes, contributing to the genetic risk associated with abdominal obesity.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The SNP rs35104205 was significant across all groups including females and males, and risk allele carriers exhibited higher expression of SREBF1 in SAT adipocytes. It also had downstream effects on numerous adipocyte-related genes.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The SNP rs12948060 was significantly associated with higher SAT adipocyte expression in risk allele carriers and was linked to 115 other adipocyte marker genes. It showed a strong impact due to its tight linkage disequilibrium with other SNPs affecting abdominal obesity.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The SNP rs4646347, like rs12948060, was associated with higher expression levels of SREBF1 among risk allele carriers, affecting a substantial number of downstream adipocyte genes due to its linkage with other signals.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The SNP rs4646346 was linked with higher expression levels of SREBF1 in risk allele carriers and impacted the same genes as its neighboring SNPs, showing significant associations with abdominal obesity traits.
title: Integration of single cell omics with biobank data discovers trans effects of SREBF1 abdominal obesity risk variants on adipocyte expression of more than 100 genes

finding: The eRNA-QTL rs11650272 was identified as independent in the regulation of BRCA1 eRNA (BRCA1e), highlighting its significant association with breast cancer.
title: Enhancer RNA transcriptome-wide association study reveals an atlas of pan-cancer susceptibility eRNAs

finding: The SNP rs62075722 exhibited recessive effects that were observed in the comparison of retinal thickness maps between heterozygotes and homozygotes. This finding related to genetic alterations that affected retinal structure, highlighting its role in genetic variation linked to ophthalmic disorders.
title: Autoencoder-based phenotyping of ophthalmic images highlights genetic loci influencing retinal morphology and provides informative biomarkers

finding: The study detected a significant association between the rs1042522 SNP in the TP53 gene and the risk of prostate cancer. The odds ratio calculated was 7.937, suggesting individuals with this variant had a substantially higher risk of developing aggressive metastatic prostate cancer, especially in those with Gleason scores greater than or equal to 8. The P72R SNP reflected a frequency of the guanine (G, R72) allele in patients with high Gleason scores, indicating its potential role in the development and severity of prostate cancer.
title: Association of the rs1042522 SNP with prostate cancer risk: a study of cancer tissues, primary tumor cultures and serum samples from a European Caucasian population

finding: Located near C1QL1, this SNP was noted as significant in the AA GIA model as a crucial predictor of dementia and was associated with progressive supranuclear palsy.
title: Improving genetic risk modeling of dementia from real-world data in underrepresented populations

finding: The SNP, rs1804145, located on SERPINF1, represented a nonsynonymous variant with a C-score of 22.8, marking it among the top 0.52% most deleterious mutations. It was significantly associated with SB (p=1.3E-6) and also suggested a link to the SB-AUD relationship with a p-value of 1.1E-7.
title: Genetic Factors Associated with Suicidal Behaviors and Alcohol Use Disorders in an American Indian Population

finding: The SNP rs8076152, residing intronic to MAPT, was associated with neuroprotective effects in the parietal lobe, retaining significance even when adjusting for diagnosis.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: Variant rs2886631 was linked to any TP53 mutation and loss of function TP53 mutations, demonstrating significant associations with P values <1.0×10^-5.
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: The variant rs2586532 was associated with PIK3CA p.E542K mutations in the AFA population, demonstrating a P value of 0.005.
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: This SNP was associated with brain age as measured by the brain age gap (BAG) and showed a highly significant p-value of 5.4x10^-21, indicating that the effective G allele was associated with an increase in brain age of 0.27 years. This SNP is located in the inversion region on chromosome 17, encompassing the MAPT gene, which had been previously mentioned in literature indexed by a different SNP (rs2435204).
title: Genetic architecture of brain age and its casual relations with brain and mental disorders

finding: The SNP rs2435204 was previously reported in relation to the MAPT gene, and in this analysis, it was found to be highly significant with respect to BAG (p=5.4x10^-21). Although it was not the lead SNP, it provided consistent findings related to brain age.
title: Genetic architecture of brain age and its casual relations with brain and mental disorders

finding: The MAPT variant showed significant associations with clusters C0 and C1, indicating its involvement in the genetic risk pathways for neurodegenerative diseases (NDDs), particularly Parkinson's disease.
title: Genetic risk factor clustering within and across neurodegenerative diseases

finding: The variant rs538628 was found within the NSF gene, known for its role as a serotonin receptor and previously implicated in autism severity. It was associated with autism and educational attainment, showing a 100% probability of shared liability with a significant p-value of 1.1e-05.
title: Exploring autism and autism co-occurring condition associations to elucidate multivariate genetic mechanisms and insights

finding: The SNP rs62059712 was identified as a major polymorphism associated with increased systolic blood pressure (SBP) in humans. The major T allele was linked to a 0.39 mmHg increase in SBP per allele copy, while the minor C allele was shown to enhance JMJD3 transcription in smooth muscle cells (SMCs) by improving SP1 transcription factor binding to the JMJD3 promoter. This transcriptional regulation led to decreased expression of the endothelin receptor EDNRB and a compensatory increase in the receptor EDNRA, ultimately contributing to hypertension (HTN) and increased arterial remodeling in the context of SMC pathophysiology.
title: Epigenetic Alteration of Smooth Muscle Cells Regulates Endothelin-Dependent Blood Pressure and Hypertensive Arterial Remodeling

finding: The SNP rs9988 was identified as a novel locus for anxiety (ANX) linked to the NUP85 gene. It occupied an exonic region, indicating its potential importance in the genetic architecture of anxiety.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: The rs11540652 SNP in TP53 demonstrated a strong association with reduced lifespan (p = 6.6 × 10^-8), highlighting the importance of TP53 in cancer-related mortality.
title: Genetic associations with human longevity are enriched for oncogenic genes

finding: The rs751713049 SNP in SRSF2 had a strong association with reduced lifespan (p = 1.9 × 10^-26), underscoring the role of this gene in longevity impairments.
title: Genetic associations with human longevity are enriched for oncogenic genes

finding: The protective allele of rs7502834 (A), located in intron 57 of the NF1 canonical transcript, was associated with increased inclusion of a 77 bp alternative exon (exon 58) via strengthening an intronic splicing enhancer motif. This event was supported by sQTL data showing that the protective allele corresponded with inclusion of this alternative exon in NF1 transcripts expressed in subcutaneous adipose tissue. Furthermore, colocalization with endometrial cancer risk signals indicated that this splicing event may provide a protective effect against endometrial cancer by reducing NF1 transcript expression.
title: Splicing annotation of endometrial cancer GWAS risk loci reveals potentially causal variants and supports a role for NF1 and SKAP1 as susceptibility genes

finding: The risk allele (A) of rs2278868 was a missense variant predicted to cause exon skipping in the SKAP1 transcript due to loss of an exonic splicing enhancer. This prediction was confirmed by sQTL data correlating the risk allele with exon 7 skipping in EBV-transformed lymphocytes. Additionally, colocalization analysis showed overlap with endometrial cancer risk signals, suggesting that reduced expression of the canonical SKAP1 transcript may increase endometrial cancer risk.
title: Splicing annotation of endometrial cancer GWAS risk loci reveals potentially causal variants and supports a role for NF1 and SKAP1 as susceptibility genes

finding: The rs138213197 SNP, which corresponds to the <italic>HOXB13</italic> c.G251G>A:p.G84E variant, was associated with a significantly increased risk of prostate cancer (PCa) in a large cohort of men. Specifically, heterozygous carriers of this variant demonstrated a higher risk of any PCa (Hazard Ratio HR 3.23), metastatic PCa (HR 2.96), and PCa death (HR 2.65). The finding was based on data from the Million Veteran Program, which included 592,158 male participants, of whom 1,660 were heterozygous for the <italic>HOXB13</italic> p.G84E variant.
title: Association of HOXB13 G84E with prostate cancer among 592,158 men

finding: The SNP rs371185851 was linked to the brain BAG and associated with the MAPT gene, which is known for its role in Alzheimer’s disease, emphasizing its importance in neurodegenerative processes.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The rs77585764 variant within the AFMID gene, with a minor allele frequency of 5.4% in METSIM compared to 0.38% in NFE, was linked to explaining 15.5% of the variance in N-formylanthranilic acid levels.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The study identified a significant association between the rs975577 variant located in the MRM1 gene and functional fecal incontinence, establishing it as a notable finding in the context of this DGBI.
title: Combined GWAS and single cell transcriptomics uncover the underlying genes and cell types in disorders of gut-brain interaction

finding: The SNP rs75010486 was recognized as a significant association with PD in both genders. For males, the P-value was 1.48E-32 with a beta of 0.244, and for females, it had a P-value of 5.02E-29 and a beta of 0.268, showing a robust genetic risk for PD.
title: Investigation of Autosomal Genetic Sex Differences in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs25531 SNP was identified as potentially influencing serotonergic signaling pathways, which were implicated in the neuroanatomical variations observed in patients with functional symptoms related to adverse life experiences. Specifically, this SNP was associated with variations in amygdala responsiveness and was linked to neurological changes that could influence functional symptom severity, as highlighted in the context of increased gray matter alterations within cingulo-insular and amygdala regions.
title: Linking gene expression patterns and brain morphometry to trauma and symptom severity in patients with functional seizures

finding: The SNP rs17763050 was confirmed to associate with the H1 haplotype in the 17q21.31 locus. This finding provided critical genotype information which was utilized in the analysis of Parkinson’s disease (PD) diagnosis, indicating its relevance in understanding genetic susceptibility to neurodegenerative diseases.
title: Single-cell atlas of transcriptomic vulnerability across multiple neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric diseases

finding: The SNP rs8070723 was also confirmed to associate with the H1 haplotype in the 17q21.31 locus. Similar to rs17763050, this finding was pivotal in the genetic analysis related to Parkinson's disease (PD), supporting the importance of this region in the genetic landscape of neurodegenerative disorders.
title: Single-cell atlas of transcriptomic vulnerability across multiple neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric diseases

finding: Found near CRHR1 in the MAPT locus, SNP rs117615688 was also replicated in the study with genome-wide significance being attained, supporting its association with PD and contributing to the shared genetic architecture between Latino and European populations.
title: Characterizing the genetic architecture of Parkinson’s disease in Latinos

finding: The SNP rs4968646 was causally linked to chronotype via altered expression of the CYB561 gene rather than TANC2, which is associated with a different SNP (rs17682747) in high linkage disequilibrium (LD). This established a novel connection between this locus and chronotype.
title: Mendelian randomisation analysis using GWAS and eQTL data to investigate the relationship between chronotype and neuropsychiatric disorders and their molecular basis

finding: Among the 214 breast cancer patients analyzed, there were 5 patients who carried the rs80356892 mutation, including 3 patients with bilateral primary breast cancer. This group represented 60% of the individuals with the rs80356892 mutation. Moreover, all 5 patients had a family history of the disease, suggesting a potential link between this SNP and hereditary breast cancer syndromes.
title: Investigation on the clinicopathological characteristics and BRCA1/2 gene variation of patients in breast cancer pedigrees in Northern Henan Province

finding: Genetically-predicted expression of ABCA8 was positively associated with risk of CHD (P=6.50×10^-7), suggesting ABCA8 as a potential therapeutic target.
title: Transcriptome- and proteome-wide Mendelian randomization to prioritize therapeutic targets for coronary heart disease

finding: The SNP rs146729640 was also significantly associated with AAO of CI in the Amish, with the common allele correlating with later onset. This finding was replicated with nominal significance in the NIA-LOAD dataset, indicating its potential importance as a novel locus associated with delayed Alzheimer's disease (AD).
title: Genetic variants in the SHISA6 gene are associated with delayed cognitive impairment in two family datasets

finding: The study established rs12936231 as a causal SNP within the <italic>IKZF3/GSDMB/ORMDL3</italic> locus. It demonstrated strong associations with chromatin accessibility and significant changes in loop interactions, suggesting that this SNP disrupts the action of upstream regulatory elements on downstream target genes.
title: Multi-omics analysis in primary T cells elucidates mechanisms behind disease associated genetic loci

finding: Located in the 17q21.31 region, rs72828815 linked to the mean diffusivity (MD) of the anterior corona radiata showed a shared genetic influence with sleep traits.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: In the 17q21.31 region, rs1991556 shared genetic influences with sleep duration while being linked to MD of the anterior corona radiata.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: Found in the 17q21.31 region, rs2239923 was linked to mean diffusivity (MD) of the anterior corona radiata, relevant for insomnia.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs57222984 in the 17q21.31 region demonstrated links to the mean diffusivity (MD) of the superior fronto-occipital fasciculus, connecting with various sleep traits.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: Located at 14q32.2, the variant rs4792897 showed significant relations with sleep traits in the fusiform.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs34349354 was found to be linked to general cognitive ability and was supported in all validation cohorts, suggesting a connection to cognitive performance, albeit with potential implications for dyslexia.
title: Discovery of 42 Genome-Wide Significant Loci Associated with Dyslexia

finding: Rs72841395 was included among the significant loci associated with dyslexia phenotype as identified in the study.
title: Discovery of 42 Genome-Wide Significant Loci Associated with Dyslexia

finding: The SNP rs78378222, located in the 3' UTR of TP53, was reported to alter the canonical polyadenylation signal from AATAAA to AATACA. This change impaired the 3'-end processing of TP53 mRNA and was associated with an increased susceptibility to multiple cancers including cutaneous basal cell carcinoma, prostate cancer, glioma, and colorectal adenoma.
title: A distinct class of pan-cancer susceptibility genes revealed by alternative polyadenylation transcriptome-wide association study

finding: The variant rs6416905 was part of a credible set identified via SuSiE analysis for circulating sclerostin levels, with a posterior inclusion probability (PIP) of 0.078. Colocalization analysis showed strong evidence of a shared causal variant between heel bone mineral density and circulating sclerostin levels with a posterior probability of 0.964.
title: A novel and efficient machine learning Mendelian randomization estimator applied to predict the safety and efficacy of sclerostin inhibition

finding: The variant rs66838809 was found to be associated with higher heel bone mineral density (P = 5.8 x 10^-38) and a protective effect against osteoporosis (OR = 0.83, P = 3.8 x 10^-17). It shared causal variants with circulating sclerostin levels with a posterior probability of 0.997 for osteoporosis.
title: A novel and efficient machine learning Mendelian randomization estimator applied to predict the safety and efficacy of sclerostin inhibition

finding: Intronic variant rs1568002709 in CRHR1, linked to the KANSL1/MAPT locus, was associated with a decreased odds ratio of 0.62, revealing implications in IPF susceptibility.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: The SNP rs77804065 in the CRHR1 gene was identified with a genome-wide significant association (p=6.04×10−14) in the European analysis. It had been documented for its relevance to alcohol consumption disorders.
title: Genome-wide investigation of maximum habitual alcohol intake (MaxAlc) in 247,755 European and African Ancestry U.S. Veterans informs the relationship between habitual alcohol consumption and alcohol use disorder

finding: Located in an intron of TNFRSF13B, which encodes TACI, this SNP is associated with B cell activation pathways critical for antibody responses.
title: Leveraging pleiotropy identifies common-variant associations with selective IgA deficiency

finding: A missense variant in TNFSF13, encoding APRIL, which is significant in B cell differentiation, complementing the function of TACI.
title: Leveraging pleiotropy identifies common-variant associations with selective IgA deficiency

finding: Found in GSDMB, this SNP is associated with childhood-onset asthma, highlighting the genetic overlap with immune-mediated diseases.
title: Leveraging pleiotropy identifies common-variant associations with selective IgA deficiency

finding: This SNP is located in an intron of IKZF3, a gene implicated in B cell development and related to certain inborn errors of immunity.
title: Leveraging pleiotropy identifies common-variant associations with selective IgA deficiency

finding: The SNP rs1078268 was identified as a shared causal variant linked to both age at onset of walking and expression of the KANSL1 gene, with a posterior probability of 0.79 for its effect in both datasets.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis of age at onset of walking

finding: This SNP was established as a shared causal variant with rs1078268 affecting both age at onset of walking and KANSL1 expression, reinforcing the findings with a strong genetic correlation.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis of age at onset of walking

finding: SNP rs2732703 was significantly associated with AD risk and was identified as an eSNP affecting ARL17A expression in blood but was associated with LRRC37A2 in brain-related eQTLs, marking its role in the AD pathway.
title: Cell-type Specific Expression Quantitative Trait Loci Associated with Alzheimer Disease in Blood and Brain Tissue

finding: SNP rs113986870 was identified as a significant brain eQTL and ct-eQTL when paired with LRRC37A2 and also influenced ARL17A expression, linking it to AD mechanisms.
title: Cell-type Specific Expression Quantitative Trait Loci Associated with Alzheimer Disease in Blood and Brain Tissue

finding: The research established that the MAPT rs17649553 T allele was linked to better verbal memory capabilities and higher small-world properties in the structural network of PD patients. These associations suggested a potential positive influence of this SNP on cognitive function among this patient population.
title: Structural network topology mediated cognitive impairment in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs11540652, a known missense mutation in the TP53 gene, was reported in samples from patients with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG). This mutation contributed to the understanding of cancer genetics, specifically as a hotspot mutation that likely leads to altered protein function in tumorigenesis.
title: A disease model for Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) with mutations in TP53 and its application for drug repurposing

finding: Similar to rs11540652, the SNP rs730882000 was also identified as a missense mutation in the TP53 gene found in two patients with DIPG. Its presence further substantiated findings of TP53 mutations playing critical roles in cancer development.
title: A disease model for Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) with mutations in TP53 and its application for drug repurposing

finding: The hotspot missense mutation rs28934575 in TP53 gene was noted in one patient with DIPG, demonstrating a linkage between this mutation and gene expression changes that may influence tumor growth.
title: A disease model for Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) with mutations in TP53 and its application for drug repurposing

finding: The SNP rs121913343 was reported as a hotspot missense mutation in TP53. Observations indicated similarities in gene expression profiles among patients with this mutation, supporting its significance in the tumorigenic context of DIPG.
title: A disease model for Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) with mutations in TP53 and its application for drug repurposing

finding: This SNP, found in patient P12, exhibited the lowest similarity to average gene expression scores among the analyzed samples, suggesting a unique impact on gene regulation potentially associated with DIPG pathology.
title: A disease model for Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) with mutations in TP53 and its application for drug repurposing

finding: The lead SNP rs62062288, located in intron 6 of the MAPT gene on chromosome 17, was associated with the affective symptom group. It demonstrated a very strong association with a p-value of 6.09×10−15. This association indicated relevance of the MAPT gene, which is involved in encoding the Tau protein and has been implicated in affective symptoms, alcohol use disorders, and risk-taking behavior.
title: Environmental profiles of urban living relate to regional brain volumes and symptom groups of mental illness through distinct genetic pathways

finding: The intronic variant rs11079173 within the PCTP locus was associated with PA(40:5)+AcO- or PG(39:5)-H-. This association reflected the role of PCTP in lipid transfer and its relevance to atherosclerotic risk, suggesting a significant connection between lipid binding and cardiovascular pathology.
title: Genome-wide analysis of blood lipid metabolites in over 5,000 South Asians reveals biological insights at cardiometabolic disease loci

finding: An association was identified between the TP53 rs1042522 C>G polymorphism and hepatoblastoma risk among Chinese children.
title: Identification of potential core genes in hepatoblastoma via bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs375822897, located within the PLEKHM1 gene on chromosome 17, was associated with high delta age in the context of brain aging, indicated by a p-value less than 0.05 in the single-SNP GWAS analysis.
title: Investigation of Genetic Variants and Causal Biomarkers Associated with Brain Aging

finding: The SNP rs56303031, found in the LINC02210-CRHR1 gene region on chromosome 17, also demonstrated a significant association with high delta age, with a p-value less than 0.05 in the single-SNP GWAS analysis.
title: Investigation of Genetic Variants and Causal Biomarkers Associated with Brain Aging

finding: The SNP rs295849, which is located near the gene LHX1, was found to modify the relationship between physical activity (PA) and HDL-cholesterol (HDL-C). Specifically, minor allele carriers of rs295849 exhibited a significantly stronger positive association between PA and HDL-C in the Women's Genome Health Study (WGHS) (p_int = 0.002). This GxE interaction was also tested in additional cohorts, revealing an even more pronounced effect on medium-sized HDL particle concentrations (M-HDL-P) with a p_int of 1.0x10^-4. The interaction effect was notably larger in cohorts with a higher proportion of women (p = 0.018). In the UK Biobank, stronger GxE effects were observed in women specifically when analyzing M-HDL-P. In MESA, rs295849 showed nominal significance for HDL-C (p_int = 0.013) without clear differences by sex, and larger HDL particle sizes correlated with stronger interactions. These findings highlighted the role of genotype in conjunction with lifestyle factors on lipoprotein metabolism, contributing insights into cardiovascular risk.
title: Refinement of a published gene-physical activity interaction impacting HDL-cholesterol: role of sex and lipoprotein subfractions

finding: The association of rs34001746 was with later menopause at the CHEK2 locus, with a highly significant p-value of 6.2 x 10^-51. Prior analyses indicated this SNP was a top association signal.
title: Rare coding variants in five DNA damage repair genes associate with timing of natural menopause

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs25531, which modifies the long allele of the 5-HTTLPR polymorphism, was an integral aspect of the investigation into SLC6A4 promoter methylation and its relationship with seasonal affective disorder (SAD). While the interaction of sunlight exposure and the rs25531 genotype was included in analyses, it was ultimately found not to significantly impact SLC6A4 promoter methylation levels. However, rs25531 was noted as a significant variant in association with depression and SAD in prior literature, emphasizing its relevance in the study of serotonergic system dynamics.
title: Summer and SERT: Effect of daily sunshine hours on SLC6A4 promoter methylation in seasonal affective disorder

finding: The variant rs1024611 was investigated in relation to the severity of COVID-19, indicating that it had an original finding linked to the disease prognosis.
title: Non-generalizability of biomarkers for mortality in SARS-CoV-2: a meta-analyses series

finding: The SNP rs12938775 was found to be an intronic variant in the gene PAFAH1B1. This identification contributed to the evidence of multiple genetic variants affecting hearing loss, illustrating the complex genetic architecture involved.
title: Population-scale analysis of common and rare genetic variation associated with hearing loss in adults

finding: The allele variations in rs4343, associated with the Alu element in ACE signaling and linked to ACE2 expression modulation, indicated a comparative analysis of frequencies across different populations.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: This SNP in RDM1 was associated with reduced CCL5 expression levels, revealing population-specific allele frequency patterns suggesting a relevant role in COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: The rs1994182 SNP was found in variations linked to MMP28, impacting immune response and showing frequency distribution that may affect COVID-19 outcomes.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: Similar to rs1994182, this SNP in MMP28 indicated population frequency characteristics associated with immune response modulation and hence COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: The observed frequency levels of rs2107538 in CCL5 gene indicated an association with immune signaling, showcasing possible implications for COVID-19 risk in the Indian population.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: The rs3817655 variant was associated with decreased CCL5 expression and revealed lower frequencies in Indians, marking a potential influence on COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: This SNP was linked with increased expression of CCL5, showing significant population-specific frequency patterns that might affect COVID-19 risk.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: The rs1024611 variant associated with increased CCL2 expression levels was found to exhibit significant population frequency differences in the Indian cohort relevant to COVID-19 severity.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: The SNP rs149932962 was associated with both testosterone and DHT levels, serving as the lead variant in the SHBG locus. It was suggested to act as a pQTL, indicating its genetic influence on SHBG protein levels, which in turn affects steroid hormone transport in circulation.
title: Steroid hormone levels vary with sex, aging, lifestyle, and genetics

finding: The rs17850455 variant mapped to a non-synonymous variant in the POLG2 gene and was associated with mtDNA-CN, contributing to mtDNA depletion phenotype.
title: GWAS and ExWAS of blood Mitochondrial DNA copy number identifies 73 loci and highlights a potential causal role in dementia

finding: The rs1642785 G>C variation was found in 63.2% of head and neck cancer (HNC) patients. The identified C allele was associated with lower transcript stability and previously linked to an increased risk of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
title: Frequencies of TP53 Germline Variations and Identification of Two Novel 3’UTR Variants in a Series of Head and Neck Cancer Cases

finding: The rs1042522 G>C polymorphism in exon 4 (p.R72P) was identified in 66.6% of cases and was noted to affect the proline-rich domain of p53, altering its function in apoptosis and growth suppression.
title: Frequencies of TP53 Germline Variations and Identification of Two Novel 3’UTR Variants in a Series of Head and Neck Cancer Cases

finding: Variants at the GSDMB locus showed significant association with overall bronchiolitis and suggested association with non-RSV bronchiolitis. The variant rs9303281 was linked with a large effect size specifically in non-RSV infections. However, there was no significant association found with RSV bronchiolitis. This indicated that GSDMB mediates the risk of bronchiolitis largely in cases caused by non-RSV viruses.
title: Genetic susceptibility to acute viral bronchiolitis

finding: The SNP rs16940 (c.2311T>C) was identified as being associated with an increased risk of contralateral breast cancer among women who had known deleterious mutations in BRCA1. In contrast, it was noted to be associated with a reduced risk in non-BRCA1 and non-BRCA2 carriers, indicating its potential role in breast cancer susceptibility.
title: Investigation of BRCA1 exon 11 genetic variations in breast cancer among Libyan women

finding: The SNP rs28934576 was identified as a common variant in the TP53 gene and had a minor allele frequency below 0.02% among the controls. This SNP served as a benchmark for comparison with rare P/LP mutations of TP53. Importantly, carriers of this SNP demonstrated similar traits to carriers of rare germline mutations, thus substantiating its relevance in cancer predisposition and risk management associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
title: A novel map of human p53 response elements uncovers evidence of selection pressures and variants similar to Li-Fraumeni Syndrome mutations

finding: SNP rs11540652 was a rare gain-of-function TP53 P/LP variant found in two sarcoma patients within the study cohort. This SNP was linked to various sarcoma types and represented a significant finding as it was associated with different sarcoma diagnoses, confirming its potential role in reducing p53 pathway activity and contributing to cancer pathology.
title: A novel map of human p53 response elements uncovers evidence of selection pressures and variants similar to Li-Fraumeni Syndrome mutations

finding: The SNP rs8178395 was significantly associated with an ADHD-adjacent ASD diagnosis, marking the first report of such a specific genetic association. It was linked to increased frequency of the minor (T) allele among individuals diagnosed with both ADHD and ASD compared to those with ADHD only or neither diagnosis. This finding underscored the genetic heterogeneity present within ADHD, distinguishing individuals with concurrent ASD, and was not previously identified in other studies focusing on ADHD or ASD.
title: Polygenic profiles define aspects of clinical heterogeneity in ADHD

finding: The rs11079983 variant in the HDAC5 gene was associated with a poorer treatment response in comparison to the 'CC' genotype.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: The SNP rs62072157 was associated with the radial distance of the right lateral ventricle and was also linked to significant shape features in various white matter tracts. Additionally, it was identified as an eQTL for the gene GNA13.
title: Genetic influences on the shape of brain ventricular and subcortical structures

finding: The rs12051560 variant found in the SLC39A11 gene showed an association with increased blood NfL levels (P = 9.94x10-9) in European ancestry participants. This variant also indicated a relationship with neurodegeneration, particularly influencing biomarkers associated with Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Genome-wide Association Study Meta-analysis of Neurofilament light (NfL) levels in blood reveals novel loci related to neurodegeneration

finding: Identified as a significant eQTL in the promoter region of the WNT3 gene by IBSEP specifically in inhibitory neurons. This SNP was not detected in prior studies, affirming IBSEP's improved identification of ct-eQTLs linked to neuronal functions.
title: A unified framework for cell-type-specific eQTLs prioritization by integrating bulk and scRNA-seq data

finding: The SNP rs62062288 was the most significantly associated locus in males with a genome-wide significance of P=6.06×10^-13, indicating a strong link to neuroticism traits along with implications for other disorders.
title: Sex-specific genetic and transcriptomic liability to neuroticism

finding: The SNP rs55955207 emerged as the most significantly associated locus for females, achieving genome-wide significance at P=3.62×10^-12, highlighting its essential role in the neuroticism phenotype.
title: Sex-specific genetic and transcriptomic liability to neuroticism

finding: The SNP rs2453583 was found to disrupt a transcription factor binding site at the SLC47A1 locus, contributing to the genetic association with gout.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: rs2645479 was associated with RPS6KB1 and showed potential implications in the inflammatory processes underlying gout.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: In the study, rs2270401 located at 17q21.1 was associated with substantial genetic effects on white blood cell (WBC) counts throughout the pregnancy and postpartum periods. It exhibited the most significant G x T interaction effect among the eight variants analyzed and showed variation in genetic effects across the five time periods. Specifically, the genetic effect of the rs2270401-A allele was 3.33 times greater in the second trimester compared to the postpartum period, with P-values indicating strong significance (P=6.44×10^-491 for the first trimester, P=1.62×10^-1223 for the second trimester, P=2.27×10^-1021 for the third trimester, P=2.06×10^-152 for delivery, and P=6.48×10^-60 for postpartum). This finding underscored its importance in the regulation of leukocyte growth during pregnancy and highlighted its role in gestation-specific genetic effects.
title: The Dynamic Genetic Atlas of 122 Gestational Phenotypes

finding: Previous research demonstrated that rs12946942 was significantly associated with severe adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, indicating its potential role in the genetic predisposition to this skeletal disorder.
title: Variants in the SOX9 transactivation middle domain induce axial skeleton dysplasia and scoliosis

finding: The rs45553935 variant, c.5207T>C in BRCA1, was identified as a founder variant along with the BRCA2 c.517-2A>G variant, which accounted for a substantial 93.5% of actionable BRCA variant carriers in the Northern Isles.
title: Two founder variants account for over 90% of pathogenic BRCA alleles in Orkney and Shetland

finding: The rs4988345 variant was significantly associated with PrCa risk (p=0.025) in the combined datasets and was found in the BRIP1 gene, which is involved in the double-strand break repair pathway.
title: Germline sequencing of DNA-damage-repair genes in two hereditary prostate cancer cohorts reveals new disease risk-associated gene variants

finding: This SNP was associated with the rapid symptom progression subtype (Subtype III) of PD.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: This SNP was identified as significantly associated with the mild progression subtype (Subtype I) of PD.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: The SNP rs8070723 was linked to reduced risk of late onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) and was found in the same LD block as a 238bp deletion at chr17:46009357 in the MAPT gene, which encodes tau protein implicated in Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: A Specialized Reference Panel with Structural Variants Integration for Improving Genotype Imputation in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD)

finding: The intergenic variant rs528757227 located at 17q24.3 had a significantly higher allele frequency in the LLFS cohort than in other populations, indicating a protective effect on eGFR traits, which was a positive original finding.
title: Discovery of genomic and transcriptomic pleiotropy between kidney function and soluble receptor for advanced glycation end-products using correlated meta-analyses: The Long Life Family Study (LLFS)

finding: The lead variant rs72807981 was identified as significantly associated with Braak NFT stage, with an odds ratio of 0.71 and a p-value of 3.9 × 10^-8. This intronic variant in the PIK3R5 gene was suggestively linked to neurofibrillary pathology.
title: Genome-wide association study of multiple neuropathology endophenotypes identifies novel risk loci and provides insights into known Alzheimer’s risk loci

finding: The rs5848 variant at the GRN locus was identified in FTLD-TDP A as associated with a strong recessive model, showing an odds ratio of 4.12, indicating a significant connection to the disease.
title: Deciphering Distinct Genetic Risk Factors for FTLD-TDP Pathological Subtypes via Whole-Genome Sequencing

finding: The SNP rs4987082 was identified among a set of SNPs that showed high credibility for regulatory functions affecting various gene expressions.
title: Unveiling Shared Genetic Links between Blood Cell Traits and Cardiovascular Diseases

finding: This SNP was also associated with a high-confidence protein truncation in a novel locus, contributing to the genetic understanding of HF.
title: Common- and rare-variant genetic architecture of heart failure across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: Identified at chr17q12, rs1075218 had a more significant association with reading ability in the multivariate analysis compared to previous dyslexia studies, marking it as a positive original finding.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of quantitative reading skill and dyslexia improves gene discovery

finding: The SNP rs7215055 was notably associated with serum triglycerides and also linked with methylation of the CpG site cg11024682 and the expression of the gene ATPAF2. This finding had a probability of colocalization H4 of 100%, indicating a robust association between the CpG and transcript.
title: Expression quantitative trait methylation analysis elucidates gene regulatory effects of DNA methylation: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: The variant rs4968782 in ACE revealed a protective effect against cardiovascular death/transplant from AF diagnosis, with a HR of 0.85 and a significant P value of 0.0014 in matched data.
title: Combining Genetic Proxies of Drug Targets and Time-to-event analyses From Longitudinal Observational Data To Identify Target Patient Populations

finding: This SNP was identified as a sex-biased expression quantitative trait loci (sb-eQTL) associated with the expression of the gene SOCS3, demonstrating a significant association in males (p=9.67×10^-8) but not in females (p=7.68×10^-4). The analysis indicated that the effect of SOCS3 expression on height was specific to males, as evidenced by strong colocalization in males (PP4=0.93) compared to females (PP4=0.05).
title: Biological sex affects functional variation across the human genome

finding: The exonic variant rs17651549 linked to the MAPT locus was connected to brain stem LBS with a p-value of 1.0E-13. It had the highest CADD score of 26.8 among examined SNPs and showed nearly complete LD with the lead SNP of a substantial genomic risk locus.
title: Beyond Volume: Unraveling the Genetics of Human Brain Geometry

finding: The SNP rs568589031 was part of a large genomic risk locus associated with brain stem morphology, with a p-value of 2.4E-16, indicating a significant relationship between multiple exonic SNPs within the region affecting several brain-related eQTLs.
title: Beyond Volume: Unraveling the Genetics of Human Brain Geometry

finding: The rs45562031-T missense variant in SLC4A1 was identified as a significant association in the pulmonary embolism subgroup (HR=3.23, P=9.7x10^-12), while showing no effect in deep vein thrombosis (HR=1.00, P=0.98). This highlighted the variant's specific impact on recurrence risk in PE patients.
title: Genomic Landscape of Thrombosis Recurrence Risk Across Venous Thromboembolism Subtypes

finding: Associated with CCL18 and CCL3 proteins, rs1130371 demonstrated pleiotropic effects as it regulated these proteins in the same direction.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with the expression of MPO as well as its protein form, indicating a consistent regulatory role in gene expression and protein levels.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: This SNP was strongly associated with CCL16 protein levels in whole blood and served as a cis-pQTL, illustrating a regulatory relationship rooted in liver gene expression.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: The SNP rs1819040 was associated with several biomarkers and showed significant associations with kidney-related conditions. Its involvement across multiple studies highlights its potential as a genetic risk factor in COVID-19 context.
title: Insight into risk associated phenotypes behind COVID-19 from phenotype genome-wide association studies

finding: The study identified a significant causal effect of DNA methylation at cg20145695 (gene body of NXN) on breast cancer risk, where increased methylation was associated with a higher risk for estrogen-receptor positive breast cancer (OR_ER+=1.51, CI95=1.02-2.24, p=0.04) and a decreased risk for estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer (OR_ER-=0.72, CI95=0.52-0.98, p=0.04). This suggested that the effects of methylation at this site were opposing depending on the breast cancer subtype.
title: Pre-diagnosis blood DNA methylation profiling of twin pairs discordant for breast cancer points to the importance of environmental risk

finding: Showed a protective effect regarding hospitalization due to COVID-19, further illustrating individual variation's impact on disease outcomes.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19 by worldwide meta-analysis

finding: The intron variant rs12951632 was identified with a p-value of 0.026. Though not as strongly associated as rs11557080, it still emerged as noteworthy in the context of risk variants for CSF alpha-synuclein aggregate status in LRRK2-parkinsonism cases.
title: LRRK2-Associated Parkinsonism With and Without In Vivo Evidence of Alpha-Synuclein Aggregates

finding: The NDP52_GE variant (rs550510, c.491G>A, p.G140E) was defined as a protective factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD) in a study analyzing a cohort of 435 AD patients. It was found that the frequency of the variant allele A was lower in AD cases compared to controls, with statistical significance (p = 0.0042) and an Odds Ratio of 0.72, indicating that the presence of this allele is protective against AD. Further analyses also revealed that the homozygous genotype AA had a protective effect with an Odds Ratio of 0.52 (95% CI: 0.26 - 1.05). Moreover, global frequency data showed a correlation between the allele A and lower incidences of AD in specific populations, suggesting a role for NDP52_GE in resilience against neurodegeneration associated with Alzheimer's.
title: A variant of the autophagic receptor NDP52 counteracts phospho-TAU accumulation and emerges as a protective factor for Alzheimer Disease

finding: This SNP in TP53 was reported as having a significant association with mLOY, with an Odds Ratio of 1.664 and a p-value of 1.44×10^-90, indicating a risk effect related to mLOY.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association meta-analysis of mosaic loss of chromosome Y in the Million Veteran Program identifies 167 novel loci

finding: The rs11567842 SNP in the SLC13A2 gene was associated with urinary citrate concentration and previously associated with blood urea nitrogen concentration. It was also nominally associated with multiple diabetic kidney disease (DKD) phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide characterization of 54 urinary metabolites reveals molecular impact of kidney function

finding: The variant rs17608766 was associated with mitral valve annular diameter in diastole, localized to an enhancer element in GOSR2, crucial for cardiac valve biology.
title: Computational estimates of mitral annular diameter in systole and diastole cardiac cycle reveal novel genetic determinants of valve function and disease

finding: This variant was one of the lead SNPs identified in systole, associated with GOSR2 and showing implications in mitral valve biology.
title: Computational estimates of mitral annular diameter in systole and diastole cardiac cycle reveal novel genetic determinants of valve function and disease

finding: The SNP rs533030436 was correlated with larger mitral valve diameter in diastole and associated with decreased risk for cerebrovascular disease phenotypes.
title: Computational estimates of mitral annular diameter in systole and diastole cardiac cycle reveal novel genetic determinants of valve function and disease

finding: The SNP rs9303277 was significantly associated with the ORMDL3 gene, which exhibited the highest expression in cholangiocytes at 22.38%. It was noted that the combination of GWAS summary statistics identified this SNP as a top-ranked risk SNP for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). Furthermore, rs9303277 demonstrated significant cell-type specific eQTL effects among various immune cells, including naive B cells and CD4+ T helper cells, highlighting its relevance in the immune microenvironment linked to PBC.
title: Combination of single cell sequencing data and GWAS summary statistics reveals genetically-influenced liver cell types for primary biliary cholangitis

finding: The SNP rs665268, corresponding to the missense mutation p.Q139R in MLX, was also nominated as a critical variant associated with PD. This gene is part of a transcriptional network affecting energy metabolism and cell signaling. The p.Q139R variant in MLX may influence PD-related pathways by increasing oxidative stress and suppressing autophagy in immune cells, marking MLX's previously unreported involvement in PD.
title: Identification of novel variants, genes and pathways potentially linked to Parkinson’s disease using machine learning

finding: The SNP rs114001633, which resulted in a missense mutation (p.Pro227Leu) in the SREBF1 gene, was identified as genome-wide significantly associated with hemorrhagic stroke in individuals with type 1 diabetes (T1D). This finding was replicated in additional T1D cohorts.
title: Whole-genome sequencing identifies variants in ANK1, LRRN1, HAS1, and other genes and regulatory regions for stroke in type 1 diabetes

finding: The missense SNP rs1801689 was located in APOH, which is implicated in lipid metabolism and hemostasis. This SNP modified the risk of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and fibrosis in individuals with NAFLD, emphasizing its role in alcohol-related liver fat accumulation.
title: Genome-wide association study of liver fat, iron, and extracellular fluid fraction in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs773553186 was identified as one of the pathogenic mutations in the TP53 gene, which was the most frequently mutated cancer susceptibility gene in ESCC. It was reported in 0.35% of ESCC patients, contributing to the overall mutation burden in this cancer.
title: Comprehensive Study of Germline Mutations and Double-Hit Events in Esophageal Squamous Cell Cancer

finding: The rs3859191-G variant was linked to GSDMA, with the COVID-19 allele increasing transcript abundance, indicating its role in pulmonary interactions.
title: Integration of GWAS and multi-omic QTLs identifies uncharacterized COVID-19 gene-biotype and phenotype associations

finding: The rs3848456-A variant associated with DLX3 showed decreased abundance of the transcript, outlining potential regulatory effects in COVID-19.
title: Integration of GWAS and multi-omic QTLs identifies uncharacterized COVID-19 gene-biotype and phenotype associations

finding: rs2070835 was found in the exonic region of the gene VAT1, which is associated with the transport of vesicular neurotransmitters, particularly those that are crucial in the basal ganglia and have implications in PD and other disorders.
title: Unveiling the Genetic Landscape of Basal Ganglia: Implications for Common Brain Disorders

finding: The SNP rs8482 was in the exon of NBR1, an autophagic adapter protein relevant to Lewy body formation in PD, highlighting a potential biological pathway involved in basal ganglia volumes and neurodegenerative disorders.
title: Unveiling the Genetic Landscape of Basal Ganglia: Implications for Common Brain Disorders

finding: rs2227322, located in the 5' UTR of the CSF3 gene on chromosome 17, exhibited a notable positive association with NLR, with a beta of 0.07 and a p-value of 4.12 x 10^-20. The CSF3 gene is linked to cytokine-related inflammatory responses, highlighting the SNP's potential implications for the immune response.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association study of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio and polygenic risk score development to explore causal association with diabetic retinopathy

finding: The SNP rs3826331 on chromosome 17 was found to have a reversed effect as a trait-increasing allele during the study's replication phase, with a beta of 0.06 (p=1.5 x 10^-6). It is an intron near the neutrophil gene PSMD3, asserting its influence on NLR.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association study of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio and polygenic risk score development to explore causal association with diabetic retinopathy

finding: The study found that the MAPT H2 haplotype-tagging variant rs8070723 was associated with an increased risk of Pick's disease (PiD), with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.35 and a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.12-1.64 (P=0.002). This association was noted in a cohort of 338 pathologically confirmed PiD cases compared to 1,312 controls.
title: Creating the Pick’s disease International Consortium: Association study of MAPT H2 haplotype with risk of Pick’s disease
