finding: The rs3803800 SNP linked to the TNFSF13 locus on chr.17p13.1 also showed an association with IgA levels (Beta=0.06, P=9.41×10^-08) and was implicated in IgA nephropathy.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: This SNP was identified in the JUP gene, which is associated with known cardiomyopathies.
title: Deep representation learning of electrocardiogram reveals novel insights in cardiac structure and functions and connections to cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs72839768 was identified as a novel finding associated with pelvic organ prolapse (POP). It was a missense variant located in the DVL2 gene, with an effect size showing a significant association (p=4.66 × 10^-9) and an allele frequency of 0.02. This SNP contributed to establishing a link between genetic determinants and the condition.
title: Advancing our understanding of genetic risk factors and potential personalized strategies in pelvic organ prolapse: largest GWAS to date reveals 19 novel associated loci

finding: The MAPT rs17649553 T allele was linked to better verbal memory and higher small-world properties in Parkinson's disease, reflecting its impact on cognitive performance and brain network efficiency.
title: Striatal dopamine depletion drives disease progression and network topology aberrations specifically by impairing left M1 network

finding: The SNP rs538628 was implicated as a lead trans-eQTL for AC126544.2, explaining more than 0.8 in the variance of expression for this respective eGene.
title: Whole Genome DNA and RNA Sequencing of Whole Blood Elucidates the Genetic Architecture of Gene Expression Underlying a Wide Range of Diseases

finding: The TP53 3'-UTR SNP rs78378222 was associated with high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC), showing a per T allele relative risk (RR) of 1.44. This finding indicated that the T allele was linked to increased cancer risk, aligning with previous associations of this allele with triple-negative breast cancer.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study of 398,238 women unveils seven novel loci associated with high-grade serous epithelial ovarian cancer risk

finding: The intronic variant rs143094271 in TNFSF13 was associated with an increased risk of HGSOC while presenting a paradoxical relationship with uterine fibroid risk.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study of 398,238 women unveils seven novel loci associated with high-grade serous epithelial ovarian cancer risk

finding: The SNP rs9889282 was identified as the most significantly associated variant with neck or shoulder pain, with a p-value of 2.63 x 10^-12, located near the CA10 gene on chromosome 17. This association revealed that the carbonic anhydrase gene may play a role in bone resorption and has been implicated in neuropathic pain.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Neck or Shoulder Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: The missense variant rs1568061110, c.737A>T (p.Gln246Leu) in the ACTG1 gene (NM_001614.5), was identified as most likely the genetic cause of autosomal dominant non-syndromic hearing loss (ADNSHL) in a five-generation family. The variant was shared by affected family members but not by those with normal hearing. Its evolutionary conservation and predictions of being deleterious were supported by various bioinformatics tools, indicating its significance in relation to the hearing loss phenotype.
title: Responsiveness of the electrically stimulated cochlear nerve in patients with a missense variant in ACTG1: Preliminary Results

finding: <italic>MAPT</italic> rs17649553 was involved in the multi-SNP models predicting higher derived total recall T-scores in female patients, showcasing its contribution to cognitive aspects of PD.
title: The multi-modality neuroimaging analysis identified an essential genetic variant associated with Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs117615688 variant in the CRHR1 gene was nominally associated with RBD with OR=1.19 (95% CI=1.05-1.36, p=0.008). This finding represented an opposite effect relative to its association with PD, indicating a complex role of this SNP in the context of sleep disorders aspect in Parkinson's disease.
title: Genome-wide association study of REM sleep behavior disorder in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs138741144, linked to cardiac septal defects, showed significant associations in a PheWAS using Peds-Phecodes with several congenital heart phenotypes including phecode 747.113 'Common ventricle' and phecode 747.13 'Congenital anomalies of great vessels'. This contrasted with the phecodes PheWAS, which identified only one association.
title: Developing and Evaluating Pediatric Phecodes (Peds-Phecodes) for High-Throughput Phenotyping Using Electronic Health Records

finding: Located at the CDK12 locus, SNP rs11078912 was identified as a novel association lowering 3-methylhistidine, an amino acid biomarker, and emphasized its connection to protein metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The rs61667602 SNP in the CRHR1 locus was identified as associated with a reduced risk of pulmonary fibrosis, OR 0.84 (p=2.26 x 10^-12). This finding was significant among the phenotypes related to respiratory complications from COVID-19.
title: A Phenome-Wide Association Study of genes associated with COVID-19 severity reveals shared genetics with complex diseases in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The variant rs62063281 was associated with an increase in IVS.csad, with a Beta value of 8.6 mm2 and a high statistical significance (p=1.3e-13). This SNP tagged a common inversion encompassing the KANSL1 gene, which plays a role in cardiac development. Furthermore, evidence indicated that this variant was linked to congenital heart defects such as ventricular septal defects (VSD), thus highlighting its significance in cardiovascular genetics.
title: Genetic determinants of interventricular septal anatomy and the risk of ventricular septal defects and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

finding: The rs12150284 variant has been established as a shared locus between primary open-angle glaucoma and primary angle closure glaucoma, indicating common pathways in glaucoma pathogenesis.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The SNP rs1008723 was found at locus 17q12 and was jointly associated with all ADs and atrial fibrillation (AF), except for primary sclerosing cholangitis-related AF. Its location in the intronic region of the gasdermin B gene (GSDMB) indicates its potential role in pyroptosis, which is implicated in the pathogenesis of both ADs and CVDs.
title: Genetic analyses identify shared genetic components related to autoimmune and cardiovascular diseases

finding: The rs373862041 variant in PPM1D was identified in two affected siblings of the European cohort. This known single nucleotide variant, c.131C>G; p.S44W, was inherited from an asymptomatic parent with a family history of autoimmune disorders, highlighting its potential role in the genetic basis of Pediatric Acute-onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome (PANS). The minor allele frequency (MAF) was reported as 0.000255, indicating its ultra-rare status.
title: Identification of ultra-rare genetic variants in Pediatric Acute Onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome (PANS) by exome and whole genome sequencing

finding: This SNP showed a strong association with tau pathology (PC1) and was specifically linked to AD risk in females (+1.61SD), suggesting a sex-specific mediation pathway.
title: Multivariate GWAS of Alzheimer’s disease CSF biomarker profiles implies GRIN2D in synaptic functioning

finding: The SNP rs1075901 was associated with BMI and located within 500kb from the UBB gene, showing a beta of 0.012 and significance P = 4.4 × 10^-13.
title: Population scale whole genome sequencing provides novel insights into cardiometabolic health

finding: This SNP spanned the genes SMG6 and SRR and was noted as the most significant eQTL for SRR in arterial tissue, indicating its relevance in ascending aortic distensibility.
title: GENOME-WIDE ASSOCIATIONS OF AORTIC DISTENSIBILITY SUGGEST CAUSAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH AORTIC ANEURYSMS AND BRAIN WHITE MATTER HYPERINTENSITIES

finding: The study revealed that the SNP rs799905 was associated with allele-specific methylation patterns among breast cancer patients. Specifically, of the individuals with concordant BRCA1 methylation in both white blood cells and tumor tissue, a substantial proportion had informative genotype information for rs799905. Among the 15 patients who were informative, the preferential methylation was observed on the same allele in both tissues for five of these individuals, indicating a shared clonal origin between the normal and tumor cells. Additionally, the analysis of newborn girls highlighted that 44.9% of those heterozygous for rs799905 exhibited predominant methylation on a specific allele, mirroring findings in adult patients. Overall, these findings underscored the relevance of rs799905 in understanding BRCA1 epimutations related to breast cancer phenotypes, particularly in triple-negative and low-estrogen receptor expression cases.
title: Prenatal BRCA1 epimutations contribute significantly to triple-negative breast cancer development

finding: Found among the novel shared SNPs, rs8882 was significant for understanding the genetics of comorbidity between the studied traits.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: This SNP was closely related to rs7221651 on chromosome 17, showing a very high linkage configuration (R² = 0.99), further supporting its involvement in chronic dizziness within the specific genetic context.
title: GWAS of Chronic Dizziness in the Elderly Identifies Novel Loci Implicating MLLT10, BPTF, LINC01225, and ROS1

finding: The SNP rs407307 showed significant associations with the phenotypes of both IBD and PBC, highlighting its role as a shared risk SNP.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs12946510 was associated with the pathogenesis of PBC by affecting FOXO1 binding affinity, indicating its importance in inflammatory processes related to both IBD and PBC.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs35296742 on the AOC2 gene was uniquely associated with a diameter approximately 13mm distal to the sinotubular junction, which was most salient for predicting instances of thoracic aortic aneurysm, highlighting its potential significance in aortic pathology.
title: Using Machine Learning to Elucidate the Spatial and Genetic Complexity of the Ascending Aorta

finding: Identified in the locus upstream of FAM20A, this SNP had significant implications for otosclerosis risk, with an odds ratio of 1.39.
title: Genome-wide Screen of Otosclerosis in Population Biobanks: 18 Loci and Shared Heritability with Skeletal Structure

finding: The SNP rs1052536 was associated with QTc duration, thus contributing to the QTc-PRS, which was significantly linked to increased QTc intervals in the studied participants.
title: Genetic QT Score and Sleep Apnea as Predictors of Sudden Cardiac Death in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs708382 was associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) and was found in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with six other variants in locus 28. It mapped to the ITGA2B gene, which is a target for the existing drug Abciximab, indicating a potential for drug repurposing for LOAD.
title: Largest GWAS (N=1,126,563) of Alzheimer’s Disease Implicates Microglia and Immune Cells

finding: The SNP rs5911, an exonic variant within the ITGA2B locus, was noted for its high CADD score of 19.8, implying significant potential functional impact. It contributed to the genetic architecture of LOAD and was associated with the same region as rs708382.
title: Largest GWAS (N=1,126,563) of Alzheimer’s Disease Implicates Microglia and Immune Cells

finding: This intergenic SNP between PHB and ZNF652 was previously linked to asthma. In this study, it was associated with ACO and reported significant chromatin interactions in ZNF652.
title: Genetic associations and architecture of asthma-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease overlap

finding: The study found that the T allele of the MAPT rs17649553 was associated with better verbal memory performance in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and exhibited higher small-world properties in brain network topology, indicating a potential link between this SNP and cognitive functions in PD.
title: High-level anxiety is associated with worse clinical symptoms and aberrant brain networks in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs62055708 SNP was confirmed as associated with Parkinson's disease, showing a C to A substitution that aligned with a delta repression score of 0.20 in neuronal stem cells, indicating altered transcriptional repression. It gained a binding site for the transcriptional activator NFE2.
title: The contribution of silencer variants to human diseases

finding: Linked to Type 1 diabetes, the rs62057121 SNP indicated a delta repression of -0.51, showing a significant regulatory role in a candidate silencer among T cells.
title: The contribution of silencer variants to human diseases

finding: The SNP rs35714695 was identified as the lead SNP in an ALS genome-wide association study (GWAS), showing significant genome-wide relevance. It was located in proximity (8.3-11.4 kb) to the strong gain-of-function variants of SARM1, reinforcing the connection between SARM1 and ALS. While rs35714695 represents a more common variant, both it and the analyzed strong GoF variants supported the notion that SARM1 could contribute to ALS pathology.
title: Enrichment of SARM1 alleles encoding variants with constitutively hyperactive NADase in patients with ALS and other motor nerve disorders

finding: This variant was located in the LINC01482 locus. It showed a PPR of 0.832 for MAMBA-G effects and a PPR of 0.510 for the GT effect, indicating notable strength in replicability. LINC01482 was previously associated with lipid-related traits based on 53 studies.
title: Statistical Assessment of Biomarker Replicability using MAJAR Method

finding: The G84E (rs138213197) variant in HOXB13 was noted in the context of prostate cancer. The research highlighted the stratification of PRS among carriers of this variant, suggesting a significant association with prostate cancer risk.
title: Breast and prostate cancer risk: the interplay of polygenic risk, high-impact monogenic variants, and family history

finding: SNP rs12949906 had enhanced expression in dendritic cells, highlighting its involvement in immune-related pathways affecting C3 protein.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: The rs66838809 variant in the SOST region was significantly associated with circulating sclerostin levels, showing an SD change with P value of 1.45 × 10^-9.
title: Lowering of circulating sclerostin may increase risk of atherosclerosis and its risk factors: evidence from a genome-wide association meta-analysis followed by Mendelian randomization

finding: SNP rs117217714 was associated with super-variant chr17_26 across three repetitions, highlighting its potential significance in COVID-19 mortality risks.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: SNP rs60811869 was associated with super-variant chr17_26, acting as an eQTL for gene WSB1, which plays a role in immune function, relevant for COVID-19 vaccine responses.
title: Genetic variants are identified to increase risk of COVID-19 related mortality from UK Biobank data

finding: The SNP rs709591 was significantly associated with MT-CN variation with a P value of 1.61×10^-4, and also linked to neutrophil count. This SNP had previously been reported in sub-threshold QTL associations for MT-CN and replicated in the Finnish dataset, indicating its role in influencing MT-CN through cell type composition.
title: Mitochondrial genome copy number measured by DNA sequencing in human blood is strongly associated with metabolic traits via cell-type composition differences

finding: This SNP was identified as a brain eQTL corresponding to multiple genes and was also linked to Parkinson's disease, suggesting its dual role in cardiovascular and neurodegenerative pathways.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This SNP was associated with bipolar disorder and multiple brain eQTLs, linking cardiovascular and psychiatric health.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This SNP indicated a connection to bipolar disorder and cerebrovascular disorders, demonstrating shared genetic influences.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This SNP was associated with regional brain volumes and genetic traits influencing cardiovascular health.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: Upstream of NEUROD2, the variant rs12453682 was noted for its association with lower apparent fiber density in tracts traversing the internal capsule and extending into the brainstem and superior cerebellar peduncles.
title: Distinct impact modes of polygenic disposition to dyslexia in the adult brain

finding: The intronic variant rs12150530 in the MAPT gene showed strong associations within impact mode capturing bilateral volume variations in the temporal lobes, highlighting its potential relevance in dyslexia.
title: Distinct impact modes of polygenic disposition to dyslexia in the adult brain

finding: The SNP rs34872586 was identified in the context of PTSD and was correlated with a shared causal variant across multiple LE8-related phenotypes, highlighting its relevance in the study of PTSD comorbidities.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The rs3803800 SNP in the TNFSF13 gene was described as a nonsynonymous variant (p.Asn96Ser). The analysis indicated that this SNP contributed to understanding disease mechanisms related to IgA nephropathy, though specific functional outcomes were not elaborated in the provided text. It aligned with the identification of non-coding regions predominating among the significant loci in the study.
title: GWAS defines pathogenic signaling pathways and prioritizes drug targets for IgA nephropathy

finding: The C allele of rs8065294 in the CACNG4 gene was significantly linked to a higher risk of IR, with a reported OR of 7.05 and a p-value of 0.0006. Under the codominant inheritance model, the T/C and C/C genotypes were recognized as contributing to this increased risk against the T/T genotype.
title: Unveiling Genetic Associations: Investigating CLDN16, GRID2, NRG3, and CACNG4 Gene Polymorphisms with Insulin Resistance Risk Among Normal BMI Individuals in the Indian Population

finding: Variant rs139356332 was associated with inflammatory traits, notably in rheumatoid arthritis, and linked to the gene MFAP4, related to inflammatory mechanisms. Its contribution revealed enrichment in periodontium and mouth tissues, aligning with epidemiological evidence connecting periodontal conditions with RA.
title: A scalable variational approach to characterize pleiotropic components across thousands of human diseases and complex traits using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs4795899-A demonstrated an association with protection from Crohn's disease while concurrently increasing the risk of ER-negative breast cancer. It was also correlated with immune cell marker expression in breast tumor samples.
title: Mapping inherited genetic variation with opposite effects on autoimmune disease and cancer identifies candidate drug targets associated with the anti-tumor immune response

finding: The synonymous variant in <italic>ASGR1</italic> was fine-mapped for alkaline phosphatase and was associated with several traits including albumin and cholesterol levels.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: Identified as a non-coding deletion variant that is independent of the synonymous variant rs55714927, influencing coronary artery disease.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: An important 3' UTR variant of <italic>TP53</italic> linked to skin cancer.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: A European-specific missense variant that was part of allelic series for eosinophil count.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: An intergenic variant associated with eosinophil count located near <italic>EPX</italic> and <italic>LPO</italic>.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: This SNP exhibited genome-wide significant associations with both thickening of the inner retinal layers and RPE+BM thinning, indicating its influence on multiple aspects of AMD pathology.
title: Photoreceptor layer thinning is an early biomarker for age-related macular degeneration development: Epidemiological and genetic evidence from UK Biobank optical coherence tomography data

finding: Rs1991556 on chromosome 17 was associated with a low odds ratio (OR) of 0.91 for PRISm per G allele. It had a strong association with FEV1 (p value 4.3×10−25) and FVC (p value 7.5×10−18), and some association with self-reported emphysema/chronic bronchitis and age of asthma diagnosis.
title: Epidemiology and Genetics of Preserved Ratio Impaired SpiroMetry (PRISm): An Analysis of UK Biobank

finding: Rs7213474, an intron variant in the ASPSCR1 gene, was noted with an OR of 1.006 per T allele. Previous associations were found with FEV1, FVC, and PEFR (all p value <0.5×10−8).
title: Epidemiology and Genetics of Preserved Ratio Impaired SpiroMetry (PRISm): An Analysis of UK Biobank

finding: This SNP showed a significant association with proteinuria in mothers (OR 2.83, p = 5.65E-06), highlighting its potential relevance to renal manifestations in preeclampsia.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: The rs799917 (T>C) variant showed a 100% frequency in normal samples and increased mutation frequency in prostate cancer among men of African ancestry. This variant was strongly associated with BRCA1 mutations, enhancing cancer risks specifically in populations of African descent.
title: Whole Exome Sequencing of Nigerian Prostate Tumors from the Prostate Cancer Transatlantic Consortium (CaPTC) Reveals DNA Repair Genes Associated with African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs8065800 at the MAPT gene locus (17q21.31) was identified as associated with severe COVID-19 in the Spanish cohort, showing a significantly high association (P=1.16×10^-8; OR=1.67 for minor allele G). This finding reinforced previous associations noted by the COVID-19 HGI.
title: New susceptibility loci for severe COVID-19 by detailed GWAS analysis in European populations

finding: The variant rs1819040, a significant inversion polymorphism at 17q21.31, demonstrated a protective effect against severe COVID-19 (meta-analysis result: P=7.61×10^-10; OR=0.89). It oversaw associations relevant to lung function.
title: New susceptibility loci for severe COVID-19 by detailed GWAS analysis in European populations

finding: The SNP rs5848 was associated with a higher risk of AD and had been part of discussed loci in previous research.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs34974290, located at the TRIM47 gene (chr17q25), was identified as the most significant risk variant for total WMH volume. It was significantly associated with fronto-parietal WMH and anterior periventricular WMH, with meta-pFDR of 0.018 and 0.049, respectively. This association indicated that rs34974290 was important in the genetic basis of spatial WMH patterns observed.
title: White matter hyperintensity spatial patterns: risk factors and clinical correlates

finding: This SNP occurred in the IKZF3 gene and was linked to both RA and severe COVID-19, underlining its significance in shared genetic traits.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: For SLE and severe COVID-19, this SNP was located in the CRHR1 gene, signifying a shared genetic locus.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: This SNP was associated with SLE and COVID-19 hospitalization, present in the CRHR1 gene, highlighting genetic connections.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: The synonymous SNV on NSF (rs199533) was suggestive in all three models and identified as the lead SNV of a locus encompassing MAPT and KANSL1, suggesting its association with AD.
title: A novel age-informed approach for genetic association analysis in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The study identified the SNP rs771699440, which corresponds to a known non-synonymous mutation at position c.626G>A (p.R209Q) in the GFAP gene. This variant was confirmed to be present in the proband in heterozygous form and was also found in the mother. In the context of Alexander disease (AxD), this finding was significant as it relates to the disease phenotype characterized by the accumulation of altered GFAP proteins, leading to the formation of Rosenthal fibers, which impair astroglial cell functions.
title: Alexander Disease: Screening and in silico functional characterization of variants on candidate gene

finding: The SNP rs239358 was associated with the APOE genotype, which plays a role in cognitive ability. Participants were categorized as APOE ε2, ε3, or ε4 carriers based on their genotype at this SNP, influencing their risk for cognitive decline and dementia.
title: Anticholinergic burden in middle and older age is associated with reduced cognitive function, but not with brain atrophy

finding: This SNP was identified as a cis-pQTL for TNFSF12, showcasing its role in protein level modulation related to inflammation.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: Intronic to APOH, it was found to play a role in the plasminogen activation system, affecting inflammatory response pathways.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The study found that the T allele of MAPT rs17649553 was associated with better verbal memory and higher small-world properties in individuals with Parkinson's disease. This suggests that individuals carrying this SNP may experience cognitive advantages, which could relate to their overall disease manifestations.
title: Structural network topology correlates with cognitive impairment in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs203462 SNP was marked as potentially deleterious and was among the genetic loci recognized for their association with pain intensity.
title: The genetic architecture of pain intensity in a sample of 598,339 U.S. veterans

finding: This locus was recognized as a novel finding associated with PCOS, located on chromosome 17 within an intronic region of the TP53 gene, which is known to influence SHBG and testosterone levels. The SNP was considered an eQTL in several tissues, including adipose tissue.
title: Understanding and Predicting Polycystic Ovary Syndrome through Shared Genetic Architecture with Testosterone, SHBG, and Inflammatory Markers

finding: The variant rs1005714 mapped to the NUP85 locus and was correlated with elevated MRPS7 and NUP85 mRNA levels in lung samples, also identified as a lung-specific expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL), suggesting its implication in SSC pathogenesis.
title: Integrative single-cell analysis of epigenomic and transcriptomic states in patients with systemic sclerosis-associated interstitial lung disease

finding: The SNP rs62075723-G was identified as an intron variant in TSPAN10, associated with thickening of the GCL layer (beta=0.13 SD per A allele, P=3.93x10^-63) and thinning of the PS layer (beta=-0.07 per A allele, P=9.53x10^-20). Additionally, it was linked to an increased risk of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) with an odds ratio of 1.12 (95% CI: 1.09-1.16, P=2.5x10^-11).
title: Insights into human health from phenome- and genome-wide analyses of UK Biobank retinal optical coherence tomography phenotypes

finding: This SNP was associated with lower SOST mRNA expression and positively correlated with increased bone mineral density (BMD) and reduced fracture risk, indicating a biological outcome consistent with sclerostin pharmacology. The associations extended across multiple skeletal-related phenotypes.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: Similar to rs9899889, this SNP demonstrated positive associations with increased BMD and reduced fracture risk while being linked to lower SOST expression.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: This variant was also associated with reduced SOST mRNA expression, higher BMD, and a significant decrease in fracture risk, reinforcing the beneficial skeletal-related outcomes.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: This SNP correlated with variants linked to increased BMD and also supported previous associations with the SOST locus, yet no connections were found regarding cardiovascular events.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: Consistent with the findings of rs7209826, this SNP was positively associated with BMD traits but lacked connections to cardiovascular-related phenotypes.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: This variant was associated with increased BMD but did not present any evident relationship with cardiovascular events or risk factors.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: Similar to rs2741856, this SNP showed positive associations with BMD while also maintaining no significant links to cardiovascular risk metrics.
title: Genetic and atherosclerotic plaque immunohistochemical analyses do not associate reduced sclerostin expression with cardiovascular events

finding: The SNP rs2555111 in the HOXB3 region was highlighted for its strong eQTL effects and was associated with both GSD and GSND. This finding revealed that the T allele was correlated with higher grip strength, showing an associative significance with muscle-skeletal tissue.
title: A GWAS for grip strength in cohorts of children – advantages of analysing young participants for this trait

finding: The novel variant rs9903642 near KAT7 was found to have a MAF of 4%, an OR of 1.32, and a significant p-value of 1.4×10^-8, indicating its role in increased risks of hospitalization due to COVID-19.
title: Common genetic variants identify targets for COVID-19 and individuals at high risk of severe disease

finding: The rs45553935 variant, corresponding to the pathogenic missense variant c.5207T>C; p.Val1736Ala (V1736A) of the BRCA1 gene, was associated with a notably higher than expected carrier frequency among the Orcadian population. The study identified V1736A variant carriers from clinical testing and genealogical data, demonstrating that the variant segregated with female breast and ovarian cancer in affected families. Notably, a comparative analysis of exome data revealed that the frequency of this variant in the ORCADES cohort was approximately 1%, which was about 480-fold higher than that observed in the UK Biobank. This indicated a significant local prevalence and suggested the implementation of targeted genetic screening for the variant in Orcadian women, especially those with ancestry from Westray.
title: Clinical case study meets population cohort: Identification of a BRCA1 pathogenic founder variant in Orcadians

finding: rs8074498 was linked to SHS-PC1 as a missense variant in ASPSCR1, a gene regulating GLUT4 that plays a role in glucose transport in response to insulin, suggesting implications for metabolic pathways in sleep health.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of composite sleep health scores in 413,904 individuals

finding: The study concluded that SNP rs6505162 in MIR423 was significantly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) risk in the Pakistani population. The genotypic frequencies were A/A 75 (35.21%), C/C 108 (50.7%), and A/C 30 (14.08%) in cases, while in controls they were A/A 34 (16%), C/C 94 (44.1%), and A/C 85 (40%). The associated P-value was 0.0009, indicating a strong correlation.
title: Investigation of Association Between microRNA Variants and Risk of Rheumatoid Arthritis

finding: The SNP rs59443763 at the PRKCA locus on 17q24.2 was genome-wide significant with a p-value of 1.4 × 10-8. It was implicated in both lipids and cardiovascular traits, and was primarily observed in African ancestry individuals.
title: Characterizing common and rare variations in non-traditional glycemic biomarkers using multivariate approaches on multi-ancestry ARIC study

finding: The SNP rs35763415, located in the PDE6G gene, was part of the 7 novel associations discovered. It was an intronic SNP identified as likely influencing regulatory mechanisms and demonstrated an active chromatin state in various cell types. It was found to belong to the polycomb sequence class associated with repressive gene expression activity.
title: Novel discoveries and enhanced genomic prediction from modelling genetic risk of cancer age-at-onset

finding: The variant rs78378222, located in the 3'UTR of the TP53 gene, was associated with both ER-negative and ER-positive breast cancer in opposite directions. This association reached a significance level of P<10^-6, highlighting the variant's potential role as a breast cancer susceptibility factor. Further research indicated an excess of positive associations at P<0.001 in the analysis, suggesting that more susceptibility variants could exist in the UTR regions.
title: Analysis of variants in untranslated and promoter regions and breast cancer risk using whole genome sequencing data

finding: Located near the BPTF gene on chromosome 17, rs2080090 had a significant association with Long COVID (OR=0.95, p=1.36x10^-08). The finding was corroborated with multiple functional links within the locus, suggesting a role in immune response.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of Long COVID identifies immune-related loci and etiological links to chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia and depression

finding: The SNP rs239358 was associated with the APOE-carrier status, specifically identifying participants with the ε2 allele. This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic risk factors for dementia as the ε2 allele is generally considered to have a protective effect against Alzheimer's disease.
title: Association between anticholinergic burden and dementia in UK Biobank

finding: Similar to rs955658 and rs9651873, rs199439 was included among the PTSD risk loci with a significant CADD score, indicating a potential impact on PTSD genetics.
title: The genetic relationships between post-traumatic stress disorder and its corresponding neural circuit structures

finding: Mapped to the MAPT gene, this SNP showed strong colocalization with education attainment, suggesting a shared genetic basis. It had substantial associations with autism central traits.
title: Exploring autism and autism co-occurring condition associations to elucidate multivariate genetic mechanisms and insights

finding: The SNP rs117836409 was associated with self-reported pack years of smoking at genome-wide significance level (P < 5 × 10^-8). This association highlighted the genetic heritability of smoking behavior.
title: Blood- and brain-based genome-wide association studies of smoking

finding: The SNP rs77548999 was positively linked to angina risk, presenting an odds ratio (OR_IVW) of 1.005 (95% CI: 1.003–1.007, p < 0.001), supporting its involvement in the risk of cardiovascular events.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: For neuroticism, rs1876829 emerged as a lead SNP in the GWAS analysis, with a very strong significance value of P=7.872e-39, highlighting its potential importance.
title: A genome-wide investigation into the underlying genetic architecture of personality traits and overlap with psychopathology

finding: The SNP rs8072451 was identified as an eQTL significantly associated with neuroticism, alongside several other eQTL SNPs linked to the CRHR1 gene.
title: A genome-wide investigation into the underlying genetic architecture of personality traits and overlap with psychopathology

finding: In the context of neuroticism, rs17689471 was reported as a significant eQTL variant associated with gene expression variations.
title: A genome-wide investigation into the underlying genetic architecture of personality traits and overlap with psychopathology

finding: The SNP rs173365 was included in the list of multiple eQTLs found to be significantly associated with neuroticism.
title: A genome-wide investigation into the underlying genetic architecture of personality traits and overlap with psychopathology

finding: Another eQTL SNP, rs11012, was found to be significantly associated with neuroticism, representing its role in gene expression regulation.
title: A genome-wide investigation into the underlying genetic architecture of personality traits and overlap with psychopathology

finding: The lead variant for the GWAS, rs1863115, had a significant p-value of 2.47 x 10^-10. This SNP is identified as a non-synonymous exonic variant associated with LRRC37A2 and an intronic variant for ARL17A. Due to its CADD score of 18.32, it was suggested to have deleterious effects, implicating LRRC37A2 in intelligence and mean reaction time based on previous GWAS.
title: Genome-wide association study in 404,302 individuals identifies 7 significant loci for reaction time variability

finding: The SNP rs62057121 exhibited a highly significant association with PSP, presenting a p-value of 7.45 × 10^-78 and a beta coefficient of -1.32, confirming its role in the MAPT region previously linked to the disease.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs242561 was identified as likely causal for PSP, with a p-value of 4.49 × 10^-74. It was located in an enhancer region that binds with the NRF2/sMAF protein complex, thus increasing transactivation of the MAPT gene.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: SNP rs242557 was genome-wide significant in association with PSP after conditioning on H1/H2 haplotype, showing a p-value of 3.68 × 10^-15, thus reaffirming its importance in the studied genetic region.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The alternative allele in homozygosis for rs8065903, associated with the SPATA20 gene, was also linked to the noFAST phenotype. This association suggests that individuals carrying this variant faced less aggressive renal disease progression compared to those with the FAST phenotype.
title: IDENTIFICATION OF MODIFIER GENE VARIANTS OVERREPRESENTED IN FAMILIAL HYPOMAGNESEMIA WITH HYPERCALCIURIA AND NEPHROCALCINOSIS PATIENTS WITH A MORE AGGRESSIVE RENAL PHENOTYPE

finding: The SNP rs553874586, located in the MMD gene on chromosome 17, was identified as a novel locus associated with the onset age of smoking. This finding was significant with a beta value of -3.77 and a p-value of 8.08 × 10^-9.
title: Evaluation of the Causal Relationship Between Smoking and Schizophrenia in Asia

finding: This variant was identified as protective against nasal polyps, with a significant association (P=2×10^-15), indicating a role in this condition.
title: Leveraging large-scale multi-omics to identify therapeutic targets from genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs113171849 exhibited a significant association with RBS-R stereotyped, with a p-value of 1.7 × 10^-7. It is intronic to the RBFOX3 gene, a splicing factor significantly expressed in the brain and linked to various neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism.
title: Clinical autism subscales have common genetic liability that is heritable, pleiotropic, and generalizable to the general population

finding: The SNP rs79146782 showed significant association with RBS-R injurious (p = 4 × 10^-7) and is found in an intron of the ASIC2 gene, which plays a role in sodium channel activity and has also been implicated in autism.
title: Clinical autism subscales have common genetic liability that is heritable, pleiotropic, and generalizable to the general population

finding: The SNP rs78378222 was linked to an increased risk of mLOX, but the effect size was noted to be lower than its association with mosaic loss of the Y chromosome (mLOY). This variant resides in the TP53 gene and showed complications in association across different biobanks due to variability in mLOX cell fractions.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: The minor allele of rs17884306 was connected with higher TMB and lower expression of the TP53 gene.
title: Germline cancer gene expression quantitative trait loci influence local and global tumor mutations

finding: The variant rs78378222, located in the 3' UTR of TP53, was associated with a significant reduction in odds of developing overall head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), showing an odds ratio of 0.62 (95% CI: 0.52, 0.73, p = 2.16×10^-8). It was identified as a protective factor particularly in European ancestry populations.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The novel splice variant rs55831773, found in ATP1B2, was associated with an increased risk of laryngeal cancer, presenting an odds ratio of 1.21 (95% CI: 1.13, 1.29, p_meta=5.1×10^-9).
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The SNP rs3027172 was identified in a study by Baranger et al. in 2016 as having a genotype that interacted with early life stress to predict problematic alcohol use. This finding highlighted its relevance in understanding the genetic factors contributing to alcohol use disorder, especially in the context of environmental influences like early life stress.
title: A single-nucleus transcriptomics study of alcohol use disorder in the nucleus accumbens

finding: The SNP rs11570508 was significantly associated with general congenital heart defects (CHD). It was located in the intronic region of CDC27 and had a beta value of 0.24 and P-value of 1.2×10−11. Furthermore, eQTL analysis indicated that this variant influenced the expression of MYL4 (P=0.0017) and KPNB1 (P=0.039) in heart tissues. Lower expression levels of these genes were confirmed in human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes from CHD patients compared to healthy controls.
title: Genomic and transcriptomic data analyses highlight KPNB1 and MYL4 as novel risk genes for congenital heart disease

finding: The SNP rs1293973611 was significantly associated with septal defects. It was found in the intronic region of RP11-1055B8.3 with a beta value of 4.96 and a P-value of 1.1×10−8. Like rs1342740627, this SNP was also enriched in the Finnish population.
title: Genomic and transcriptomic data analyses highlight KPNB1 and MYL4 as novel risk genes for congenital heart disease

finding: The SNP rs1202093388 (17:42372576:G:C) was identified as a very rare variant with significant association with prostate cancer (OR 9.4, p-value 5.1 x 10^-8), although it could not be replicated due to its rarity. Its lead non-coding variant was located downstream from SNORA40, which codes for small nucleolar RNA potentially involved in cancer biology. This finding highlighted the importance of investigating rare variants in understanding cancer susceptibility.
title: FinnGen: Unique genetic insights from combining isolated population and national health register data

finding: Similar to rs9264393, this SNP showed numerous significant phenotypic associations across multiple traits associated with CHIP.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: This SNP was associated with several health traits, particularly within blood cell counts and biomarker levels outlined in the UK Biobank data.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: This variant in NEURL4 was linked to TP53-CHIP as a risk-increasing missense variant, with an impressive odds ratio of 1284.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs36082764 was associated with the long non-coding RNA LINC00511 at 17q21.31, demonstrating a Beta of -0.62, SE of 0.11, and a P-value of 6.3e-8, suggesting its involvement in PD axial motor progression.
title: Association of genetic variation at the GJA5/ACP6 locus with motor progression in Parkinson’s

finding: The rs113282988 variant, an intronic variant in ITGAE, interacted with the trauma risk score (TRS) to significantly increase the risk of developing PTSD, with a beta coefficient greater than 0.056 (p<3.28×10<sup>-9</sup>). This finding suggested a role of ITGAE in PTSD, notably in mechanisms involving T-lymphocytes and immune response.
title: Disentangling the roles of trauma and genetics in psychiatric disorders using an Electronic Health Records-based approach

finding: The SNP rs1799941 in the SHBG locus interacted with sex impacting testosterone levels, making it a notable finding in variance analysis.
title: Hypothesis-free detection of gene-interaction effects on biomarker concentration in UK Biobank using variance prioritisation

finding: The SNP rs60380775 was associated with stroke of any mechanism, as identified in the TOPMed program's analysis that aimed to reveal susceptibility loci driven by rare variants.
title: Whole Exome Sequencing Analyses Support a Role of Vitamin D Metabolism in Ischemic Stroke

finding: The data indicated that the G-rs2628315 allele, which is in perfect linkage disequilibrium with the risk-associated C-rs2787486 allele, was preferentially expressed in breast cancer cases compared to controls. This preferential expression was associated with a significant risk for breast cancer.
title: Germline Allelic Expression of Genes at 17q22 Locus Associates with Risk of Breast Cancer

finding: The analysis showed that the A-rs17817901 allele was preferentially expressed in cases compared to controls, associating this finding with an increased risk of breast cancer. The allele was also in strong linkage disequilibrium with the risk variant rs2787486.
title: Germline Allelic Expression of Genes at 17q22 Locus Associates with Risk of Breast Cancer

finding: This rSNP was found to alter the binding motif for the transcription factor TCF3, thus influencing the expression of associated genes and suggesting an oncogenic role in breast cancer risk.
title: Germline Allelic Expression of Genes at 17q22 Locus Associates with Risk of Breast Cancer

finding: This variant was previously identified as associated with an increased risk for breast cancer, with a per-allele odds ratio of 0.95, indicating its role as an important genetic factor in breast cancer susceptibility.
title: Germline Allelic Expression of Genes at 17q22 Locus Associates with Risk of Breast Cancer

finding: The variant served as the lead risk SNP in the region, showing a strong association with breast cancer risk with an odds ratio of 0.92, validating its importance in the genetic background of the disease.
title: Germline Allelic Expression of Genes at 17q22 Locus Associates with Risk of Breast Cancer

finding: The SNP rs4791212 was associated with overall macular thickness of the right eye and shared influences with the mean measure of the inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, showing a posterior probability of PPH4 = 0.963.
title: Eye-brain connections revealed by multimodal retinal and brain imaging genetics in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12451721 showed shared genetic influences with brain imaging traits related to the mean measure of the inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, highlighting its role in eye-brain connections.
title: Eye-brain connections revealed by multimodal retinal and brain imaging genetics in the UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was identified in the context of LVMI and was associated with multiple candidate genes. It was particularly noted for its proximity to the FLNC gene, which has been previously linked to various forms of cardiomyopathy, highlighting its potential role in cardiac structural integrity.
title: Clinical and Genetic Associations of Deep Learning-Derived Cardiac Magnetic Resonance-Based Left Ventricular Mass

finding: This SNP was located on chromosome 17 and was found near WNT3. It was associated with LVMI in the study, and the implications of its function pointed towards mechanisms relevant to cardiomyocyte function and potentially underlying cardiac diseases.
title: Clinical and Genetic Associations of Deep Learning-Derived Cardiac Magnetic Resonance-Based Left Ventricular Mass

finding: SNP rs2301369 was associated with the NOS2 gene, showing significance across multiple studies (OR = 1.08, p = 3.9 × 10−8). The NOS2 enzyme is crucial for nitric oxide production in response to inflammation, linking it to anterior uveitis and immune response mechanisms.
title: Genome-wide association study of anterior uveitis

finding: This exonic SNP was identified in the analysis as part of a novel anxiety locus but without extensive discussion about its functional implications.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: The variant rs80357880 was identified as a frameshift insertion (p.L655Ffs*10) in exon 9 of the BRCA1 gene in one breast cancer patient. This variant was classified as pathogenic in ClinVar and has been associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. According to the OncoKB database, it was classified as likely oncogenic with a Level 1 evidence classification, indicating its recognition as a predictive biomarker for response to multiple FDA-approved drugs, including PARP inhibitors.
title: A workflow for clinical profiling of BRCA genes in Chilean breast cancer patients via targeted sequencing

finding: The sequence variant rs3809863 was found to be significantly associated with astigmatism and open-angle glaucoma. It was located on chromosome 17 within the genic region of ITGB3 and THCAT158, close to cCREs, indicating a high transcription activity in various brain tissues. This variant additionally showed a robust association with brain disease-related phenotypes, suggesting a possible link between intraocular pressure elevation and retinal damage in glaucoma.
title: A novel computational methodology for GWAS multi-locus analysis based on graph theory and machine learning

finding: The rs67143157 SNP from the ASGR1 locus was significantly associated with Endoglin levels with a reported p-value of 1.83 x 10^-8, linking its genetic influence on plasma protein levels of Plasminogen Activator, Urokinase Receptor.
title: Non-canonical regulation of Endoglin by rare and common variants: new molecular and clinical perspectives for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia and beyond

finding: This SNP in the SOX15-SAT2 locus associated with oestradiol-F with a beta of 0.0363 (P=1.02E-12), highlighting its biological significance in hormone-related fertility issues.
title: Genome-wide analyses identify 21 infertility loci and over 400 reproductive hormone loci across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: The variant rs2011959, located downstream of CCL3, was associated with severity in men with an OR of 1.34 and P=6.50×10−6.
title: A year of COVID-19 GWAS results from the GRASP portal reveals potential SARS-CoV-2 modifiers

finding: The recessive variant rs1728177 on DHX8 showed a genome-wide significant association with stroke (p-value=7.19×10^-9). However, it did not replicate in further studies.
title: Whole genome sequencing identifies rare variants in ANK1, LRRN1, HAS1, and other genes and gene regulatory regions for stroke in type 1 diabetes

finding: The rs142653327 variant was identified as a novel pQTL for Gal-9 in Greenland, which is not present in European populations, highlighting its unique clinical significance.
title: Genetic regulation of the plasma proteome and its link to cardiometabolic disease in Greenlandic Inuit

finding: The rs112305547 variant was significant within the primary association for Gal-9 in Greenland, showing it as a common variant impacting protein expression.
title: Genetic regulation of the plasma proteome and its link to cardiometabolic disease in Greenlandic Inuit

finding: The locus tagged by lead variant rs77534576 was discovered in the critically ill COVID-19 analysis, indicating a significant association with severe manifestations of COVID-19.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19 by worldwide meta-analysis

finding: The missense variant rs72553883 in TNFRSF13B was associated with spleen volume, with an effect of 0.025 L and an effect size of 0.37 standard deviations (P = 5.6 × 10^-19). This finding underscored the link between spleen abnormalities and the functional role of TNFRSF13B in individuals with common variable immunodeficiency.
title: Mapping rare protein-coding variants on multi-organ imaging traits

finding: The missense variant rs34557412 in TNFRSF13B was the top hit among variant-level associations with spleen volume, exhibiting an effect of 0.028 L and an effect size of 0.42 standard deviations (P = 2.0 × 10^-28). This variant further supported the relationship between the gene and splenomegaly.
title: Mapping rare protein-coding variants on multi-organ imaging traits

finding: The rs369903296 SNP, a missense SNV in ERBB2 resulting in Arg599Cys (R599C), was identified in three unrelated probands with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) defects. It showed reduced penetrance as the variant was found in all affected family members, but two unaffected family members also carried the variant. This finding illustrated a familial pattern of inheritance for the variant.
title: ERBB2 R599C variant is associated with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction defects in human

finding: The SNP rs34081637 was associated with a shift of the P wave and PR interval in the context of Brugada syndrome (BrS). This SNP is located at the CACNA1G locus, which encodes for the voltage-dependent calcium channel, T-type, alpha 1G subunit, a crucial component of calcium handling in the heart. The study posited that the altered activity of this genetic locus could influence ECG morphology, particularly in relation to BrS, even though pQTLs or eQTLs directly correlating to CACNA1G were not identified.
title: N-Palmitoyl glycine activates transient receptor potential channel 5 and increases the risk of Brugada syndrome

finding: This SNP was linked to VTE as a common 66bp structural variant, representing the importance of including such variants in GWAS.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs11079650 was recognized as a strong novel association, located intronically within the PRKCA gene on chromosome 17. Prior studies linked this locus with electrocardiographic measures of left ventricular mass and dilated cardiomyopathy, now affirming its genome-wide significance.
title: Multi-ancestry Multivariate Genome-Wide Analysis Highlights the Role of Common Genetic Variation in Cardiac Structure, Function, and Heart Failure-related Traits

finding: The SNP rs9912468 was noted as a cis-eQTL for PRKCA, in perfect linkage disequilibrium with rs11079650. This finding suggested a possible cardiac-specific enhancer activity at this locus, corroborated by functional studies demonstrating its effect on PRKCA expression.
title: Multi-ancestry Multivariate Genome-Wide Analysis Highlights the Role of Common Genetic Variation in Cardiac Structure, Function, and Heart Failure-related Traits

finding: The variant in the promoter of GAA, identified 182 bps upstream of the transcription start site, was found in trans with a nonsense variant in a proband with a phenotype similar to limb girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD). Although in silico scores indicated it was unlikely to be deleterious, biochemical assays confirmed marked deficiency in GAA enzymatic activity, leading to a diagnosis of Pompe disease.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: The nonsense variant identified in GAA was associated in a proband with LGMD. Despite earlier normal GAA enzymatic testing, subsequent assays confirmed a marked deficiency in GAA activity, establishing a diagnosis of Pompe disease, emphasizing a clinical relevance for both variants found in this proband.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: The 5'UTR intronic variant, identified in cis with the promoter variant in GAA, was reported pathogenic in ClinVar and found in a significant percentage of Pompe disease cases. It was implicated in splicing impacts, demonstrating additional complexity in the genetic landscape of GAA in a proband with LGMD.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: Found on chromosome 17 at locus 17q21.31, with a z-score of 7.11. It was strongly associated with the left middle frontal cortex connectivity, qualifying as a new association in brain connectivity.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: Also found on chromosome 17 at locus 17q21.31, this SNP exhibited a z-score of 6.66, further linking to the left middle frontal cortex connectivity, marking a new connection in genetic studies of brain metrics.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs9915190 was associated with the CASC17 region influencing SOX9 gene regulation. Its significance was corroborated by recent research indicating its impact on craniofacial features.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: The SNP rs1053004, associated with the STAT-3 gene, was identified as linked to FOLFIRI-related gastrointestinal toxicity in colorectal cancer patients. This finding demonstrated the relevance of the JAK/STAT pathway in the context of intestinal dysbiosis and tumorigenesis, as highlighted in the study.
title: Vitamin D receptor protects against dysbiosis and tumorigenesis via the JAK/STAT pathway in intestine

finding: The rs315506 SNP, located on chromosome 17q11.2, was significantly associated with the spatial distribution of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in the cytoplasm, as indicated by the metric Cytoplasm_RadialDistribution_RadialCV_ER_3of4. The minor allele frequency (MAF) was 0.08, and the variant exhibited a beta of -0.52 with a p-value of 1.4×10^-10. This finding demonstrates the importance of this intergenic variant in influencing the cellular morphology with respect to ER distribution in colonies.
title: High-dimensional phenotyping to define the genetic basis of cellular morphology

finding: The SNP rs4643373 was identified in a genome-wide association study as being significantly associated with both insomnia symptoms and various cardiovascular diseases (CVD) including coronary artery disease (CAD) and myocardial infarction. It was shown to co-localize with causal signals for insomnia and CVD, indicating a shared genetic pathway. The analysis demonstrated that this SNP influences the expression of multiple genes linked to both sleep and cardiovascular function. Additionally, the locus near rs4643373 encompassed genes involved in diverse functional mechanisms such as energy metabolism and post-transcriptional regulation, emphasizing the complexity of the genetic relationships between CVD and insomnia.
title: Identifying novel links between cardiovascular disease and insomnia by Drosophila modeling of genes from a pleiotropic GWAS locus

finding: The SNP rs587780249 corresponded with a D1138N mutation on BRIP1, associated with significant disease states due to its conservation.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs1057518847 caused a D1138G mutation on BRIP1, similarly significant in terms of conservation and disease state associations.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs80356880 resulted in T37K mutation in BRCA1 influencing breast, ovarian, and pancreatic cancer as well as Fanconi anemia.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs76014915 was associated with eQTL activity in brain tissues and the tibial nerve, demonstrating its role in influencing gene expression in these specific tissues.
title: Mechanisms of tissue-specific genetic regulation revealed by latent factors across eQTLs

finding: The SNP rs267606711 was associated with agammaglobulinemia 6, an immunodeficiency characterized by low or absent serum antibodies and low or absent circulating B cells. This mutation in the CD79B gene indicated a role in blood cell indices, correlating with TWAS results which showed strong associations with various hematological traits including lymphocyte count and hematocrit.
title: Transcriptome-wide association study in UK Biobank Europeans identifies associations with blood cell traits

finding: SNP rs882367 had genome-wide significant results in both the recent UKB GWAS and in the earlier EUR-specific meta-analysis.
title: Genetics of skeletal proportions in two different populations

finding: The study identified rs10278 as a coding variant within the gene CALCOCO2, which was highlighted as the most likely causal variant at the T2D GWAS locus usually named for TTLL6. The physiological clustering suggested that this locus impacts disease risk primarily by modulating beta cell function. In the CRISPR screen conducted, knockout of CALCOCO2 consistently led to a decrease in insulin content, correlating with the risk allele's association with diabetes-related phenotypes.
title: A genome-wide CRISPR screen identifies regulators of beta cell function involved in type 2 diabetes risk

finding: This SNP was found to control WFKN2 levels and was consistent with other pQTL and eQTL studies. It was associated with regulatory marks, highlighting its importance in gene expression relevant to adipose tissue function.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The S209F variant of ABI3 (rs616338:p.Ser209Phe) was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.43 and a p-value of 4.5 × 10⁻¹⁰, indicating a significant association. The minor allele frequency (MAF) for this variant was reported as 0.008, highlighting its rarity in the population. This finding was crucial as ABI3 is a component of immune-related genes implicated in AD pathology, specifically related to microglial activity in the brain, where its loss was observed to correlate with decreased amyloid plaque burden in a mouse model of AD.
title: ABI3 deletion in TgCRND8 mice is associated with reduced amyloid plaque pathology and altered glial response

finding: The study demonstrated that the C allele at rs12938658 increased the expression of the FLOT2 gene in pre-menarcheal females, whereas its effect trended in the opposite direction in post-menarcheal females. The expression of FLOT2 has been implicated in asthma risk through previous transcriptome-wide association studies.
title: Analysis of transcriptional changes in the immune system associated with pubertal development in a longitudinal cohort of children with asthma

finding: The SNP rs12938775 was associated with PAFAH1B1, which showed weak prior evidence for being causal in depression. This variant had expression QTL associations with PAFAH1B1 and was located within a PAFAH1B1 intron, which was important for Rho GTPase activation. Despite not having the highest locus to gene score, PAFAH1B1 was prioritized due to its synaptic protein role and higher, more specific brain expression compared to the top-scoring gene CLUH.
title: An atlas of protein-protein associations of human tissues prioritizes candidate disease genes

finding: The SNP rs4968783 was identified as being associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease when lowering systolic blood pressure via angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. The odds ratio (OR) was 13.20 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 2.14 to 81.24 (p=0.005), indicating a significant relationship.
title: Repurposing antihypertensive drugs for the prevention of Alzheimer’s disease: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: The rs1800012 SNP located in the COL1A1 gene was positively associated with musculoskeletal degenerative diseases. This finding was supported by a meta-analysis which indicated that this polymorphism may play a role in the susceptibility to various connective tissue disorders and possibly impact bone properties, as it is related to collagen composition and function.
title: Collagen (I) homotrimer potentiates the osteogenesis imperfecta (oim) mutant allele and reduces survival in male mice

finding: The SNP rs12946510, known to affect transcription factor (TF) binding, significantly impacted DNA breathing by affecting 11 base-pairs around the SNP. This finding was based on the calculated q-factor scores indicating an influence on local DNA dynamics.
title: Examining DNA Breathing with pyDNA-EPBD

finding: This SNP was associated with blood pressure (P = 2 x 10^-46) and QRS interval duration (P = 1 x 10^-44) and was intronic to GOSR2, looping to the WNT9B gene.
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: This SNP was associated with two cancer-related mutations, S310Y and S310F, which occur in the HER2 protein and significantly disrupt the binding of Pertuzumab, a therapeutic antibody used in breast cancer treatment. The presence of this germline variation has been linked to drug resistance against Pertuzumab due to its impact on the interaction interface.
title: Computational Engineering of a Therapeutic Antibody to Inhibit Multiple Mutants of HER2 Without Compromising Inhibition of the Canonical HER2

finding: The SNP rs273534, located on Chromosome 17, was reported to have significant associations with both general cognitive ability and Reaction Time. The strongest association was with Reaction Time, suggesting a focus on speeded abilities rather than a broad cognitive g association.
title: Genetic “General Intelligence,” Objectively Determined and Measured

finding: The finding indicated strong allele-specific expression (ASE) at this locus, which was located in an intron of the BPTF gene and overlapped a fetal-specific ATAC-seq peak. This variant was associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk and HDL cholesterol levels but did not function as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) in the adult pancreas, suggesting its functional relevance was likely limited to the fetal pancreas.
title: iPSC-derived pancreatic progenitors are an optimal model system to study T2D regulatory variants active during fetal development of the pancreas

finding: The rs4792891 variant was strongly associated with beat synchronization and was found on chromosome 17 within the MAPT gene region. This locus is known to be associated with Parkinson's disease, linking it to neurological functions related to rhythm.
title: Genome-wide association study of musical beat synchronization demonstrates high polygenicity

finding: The SNP rs25531 was found to be associated with susceptibility and severity of cancer-related fatigue in colorectal cancer patients.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The TP53 SNP rs8064946 was identified as a top variant associated with osmotic hemolysis. It positively correlated with lipid peroxidation markers and was linked to lower osmotic fragility in RBCs.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: This SNP, located within the PRKCA gene, was given high attention by the G2PT framework, resulting in a moderate association with the TG/HDL phenotype (p = 3.5x10-7), although it did not meet the genome-wide significance threshold.
title: Mechanistic genotype-phenotype translation using hierarchical transformers

finding: The univariate gge test detected rs10278 on chromosome 17 to be associated with HDL. However, it did not provide any distinct, independent locus, as it was in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with other significant SNPs.
title: A multivariate approach to joint testing of main genetic and gene-environment interaction effects

finding: In the context of young onset ischemic stroke, the rs6565653 variant in the SLC26A11 gene showed a suggestive association with a p-value of 5.51×10^-7 in a Caucasian population. Furthermore, this variant was noted to tag RNF213 rs12944088, a missense variant that was more prevalent among subjects with intracranial aneurysms compared to healthy individuals.
title: RNF213 variation, a broader role in neurovascular disease in Caucasian and Japanese populations

finding: Similar to rs6565653, the rs12601526 variant in SLC26A11 was also associated with young onset ischemic stroke, with a suggestive p-value of 1.14×10^-6. Given its proximity to RNF213, it is probable that rs12601526 may tag associated RNF213 variants.
title: RNF213 variation, a broader role in neurovascular disease in Caucasian and Japanese populations

finding: The rs12944088 variant (p.H4691R) in RNF213 was determined to be tagged by the SLC26A11 variant rs6565653, and its minor allele frequency (MAF) was found to be higher in subjects with intracranial aneurysms compared to healthy controls in a French-Canadian study, indicating a potential role in cerebrovascular disorders.
title: RNF213 variation, a broader role in neurovascular disease in Caucasian and Japanese populations

finding: The SNP rs17608766 was identified as the lead SNP for multiple cardiac traits including aortic root size, blood pressure, and QRS complex. It was located in a D2 mesoderm-specific enhancer that showed interaction with the promoter of WNT3, a gene involved in cardiac mesoderm induction. Deletion of the enhancer harboring this SNP resulted in a significant reduction in WNT3 expression in mesodermal cells.
title: 3D Chromatin Architecture Remodeling during Human Cardiomyocyte Differentiation Reveals A Role Of HERV-H In Demarcating Chromatin Domains

finding: The SNP rs2246577 was found in the DNA binding site (DBS) of the gene FN3KRP, which is associated with a high derived allele frequency (DAF) in all three modern populations (CEU, CHB, YRI). It exhibited a positive effect size (ES) greater than or equal to 0.5 across 44 out of 48 GTEx tissues, indicating its significant role in gene expression related to protein deglycation, influencing brain development and adaptation.
title: Human-specific lncRNAs contributed critically to human evolution by distinctly regulating gene expression

finding: The G245D variant in TP53 was recognized as pathogenic and contributed to a range of cancers as part of Li-Fraumeni syndrome. This finding highlighted the significance of TP53 mutations in cancer predisposition.
title: An efficient and adaptable workflow for editing disease-relevant single nucleotide variants using CRISPR/Cas9

finding: The R248Q variant in TP53 was noted as pathogenic and associated with several cancers in the context of Li-Fraumeni syndrome, reinforcing the role of TP53 mutations in cancer risk.
title: An efficient and adaptable workflow for editing disease-relevant single nucleotide variants using CRISPR/Cas9

finding: The analysis of SNP rs8070723 in the 17q21.31 region, associated with the MAPT gene, demonstrated a high Jaccard similarity score of 0.94 between H2-carrier status and the presence of a duplication in this genomic region. A logistic regression model using H2-carrier status as a predictor achieved a 97% accuracy and an AUC of 0.95 for identifying duplications in the dataset, with minimal false positives and no false negatives.
title: CNV-Finder: Streamlining Copy Number Variation Discovery

finding: The study demonstrated that a higher expression level of ERN1 in monocytes was associated with the AS risk allele G at SNP rs196941. This finding highlighted the relationship between this SNP and the expression of a key gene involved in Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), suggesting that ERN1's role in trained immunity is significant in the pathology of AS.
title: Trained immunity in human monocyte enhances myeloid-T-cell pathogenic crosstalk in Ankylosing Spondylitis

finding: The SNP rs62074125 was found to reside within the intron of the WNT3 gene on chromosome 17 and showed a log10 Bayes factor (B10) of 2.64, indicating considerable evidence of its causal relationship with cognitive function, particularly in the context of cognitive resilience.
title: Identification of 13 independent genetic loci associated with cognitive resilience in healthy aging in 330,097 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: Various studies reported that rs7210937 in hsa-miR-1269b was significantly associated with different types of cancers, including a complete association with breast cancer (BC). The association was particularly noted in populations with differing genetic risk factors.
title: Signatures of genetic variation in human microRNAs point to processes of positive selection related to population-specific disease risks

finding: At the risk locus marked by rs8079075, this variant was analyzed and reduced the candidate causal variants set to one, highlighting its important role in enhancer activity.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: At the 17q12 locus marked by rs112569955, the 'G' risk allele displayed a 36% increase in enhancer activity compared to the non-risk 'A' allele.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The SNP rs63751273 was associated with a female individual in her 50s who had frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and carried the P301L autosomal dominant mutation. This context highlighted its relevance in neurodegenerative disorders, specifically its connection to tau pathology.
title: Small Molecule Inducers of Neuroprotective miR-132 Identified by HTS-HTS in Human iPSC-derived Neurons

finding: The SNP rs63751273 was associated with a tau-P301L autosomal dominant mutation observed in a patient-derived neural progenitor cell line (MGH2046-RC1). This mutation was related to frontotemporal dementia (FTD) pathology, thereby linking the genetic variant to neurodegenerative disease phenotypes.
title: mTOR inhibitor-independent Autophagy Activator Ameliorates Tauopathy and Prionopathy Neurodegeneration Phenotypes

finding: The variant rs115215854, an intron variant in the RPTOR gene on chromosome 17, was significantly associated with body fat percentage and weight in the Malagasy cohort. This locus showed low allele frequency (~3%) specific to African populations or those with admixed African ancestry, indicating a novel genetic connection for body composition traits not previously observed in other global populations.
title: Whole-genome Studies of Malagasy People Uncover Novel Body Composition Associations

finding: The SNP rs62070643 served as the main SNV for two distinguishable modifier effects in the chromosomal region containing ATAD5, TEFM, and ADAP2, associated with CAG expansion.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs117662433 was a notable modifier SNV (17ABEM1) that contributed significantly to increased somatic expansion, highlighting its importance in the chromosomal region.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs8067252 tagged the second modifier effect (17ABEM2) associated with increased somatic expansion, indicating distinct genetic influence in the region.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects
