finding: The SNP rs36069870 was associated with exon levels of SUMO2, a small ubiquitin-like protein, and colocalized with GWAS variants for sex hormone binding globulin levels. This association suggested that the SNP plays a role in transcriptional regulation potentially influencing these hormone levels.
title: Disentangling genetic effects on transcriptional and post-transcriptional gene regulation through integrating exon and intron expression QTLs

finding: The zinc transporter gene SLC39A11 (rs11869908) was described as linked to multiple cancers, emphasizing its potential implications in AML.
title: Iterative feature selection method to discover predictive variables and interactions for high-dimensional transplant genomic data

finding: The SNP rs9893132 was associated with SLE and was situated in an enhancer regulated by the transcription factors SP1 and NFKb2. This SNP was linked to the non-coding RNA MALAT1 and the gene cathepsin W (CTSW) in the primed macrophage eGRN. Both target genes were located more than 50kb away from the SNP, suggesting a long-range regulatory effect. The study implied that the SNP might target MALAT1, which has been implicated in SLE through multiple studies, indicating its relevance in the disease context.
title: GRaNIE and GRaNPA: Inference and evaluation of enhancer-mediated gene regulatory networks applied to study macrophages

finding: The SNP rs7214041 in the LINC00673 gene was replicated and confirmed its association with pancreatic cancer risk, consistent with prior studies.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS assessment on genetic susceptibility to pancreatic cancer

finding: The SNP rs11655237 was successfully replicated with strong evidence previously associating it with pancreatic cancer risk.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS assessment on genetic susceptibility to pancreatic cancer

finding: The SNP rs7212610, located near the long intergenic non-protein coding RNA LINC02073, achieved the highest posterior probabilities in both log-NL and log-LM models, indicating a significant gene-by-treatment (G×T) interaction and a reduction of effect size upon treatment.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs4796224, neighboring the ZNHIT3 gene implicated in severe encephalopathy, showed a high posterior probability of crossover interaction, indicating that the effect of treatment varied greatly depending on the genotype.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: This tau protein-coding SNP showed strong selection signals, relevant to neurodegenerative disorders, and contributes to an understanding of disease susceptibility.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: The rs78378222 variant in the TP53 3'-UTR was linked to cranial growth, with predicted deleterious effects (CADD = 15.93) explaining its role in the p53 signalling pathway. This finding highlighted a comprehensive involvement of p53 in regulating cranial growth processes.
title: Genetic variants for head size share genes and pathways with cancer

finding: The SNP rs7225002 at 7q21.31 was significantly implicated in influencing multiple non-FA measures within the context of white matter microstructure.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: Variant rs593720 displayed strong effects on white matter microstructure, specifically linked to traits associated with neurological and psychiatric disorders.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: The SNP rs2305480 was identified as an sQTL for the gene GSDMB, with its alternative allele C leading to skipping of exon 6, which plays a role in pyroptotic activity. This SNP was associated with lower asthma risk, providing a functional connection between splicing variants and asthma incidence.
title: Identification and analysis of splicing quantitative trait loci across multiple tissues in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs11078928 was also identified as an sQTL for GSDMB, where the C allele was associated with skipping of exon 6. This variant promoted expression of GSDMB isoforms that excluded this exon, linking it to asthma risk with the T allele being associated with a higher incidence.
title: Identification and analysis of splicing quantitative trait loci across multiple tissues in the human genome

finding: In the study, rs66826786 was associated with expression of ERBB2 only after treatment with rhinovirus (RV) in airway epithelial cells. The asthma risk allele, rs66826786-T, was linked to decreased expression of ERBB2, suggesting a regulatory mechanism influenced by RV exposure. Mendelian randomization indicated that the effect of this SNP on ERBB2 expression was mediated through differential DNA methylation at the nearby meCpG cg17401724.
title: Multi-omics co-localization with genome-wide association studies reveals a context-specific genetic mechanism at a childhood onset asthma risk locus

finding: rs12603332 showed co-localization with eQTL for ORMDL3, but this association was only significant in vehicle-treated airway epithelial cells. The finding suggested that the SNP's influence on gene expression was blunted in the presence of rhinovirus, emphasizing the role of environmental exposure in modulating genetic effects on asthma risk.
title: Multi-omics co-localization with genome-wide association studies reveals a context-specific genetic mechanism at a childhood onset asthma risk locus

finding: The SNP rs78378222 in the TP53 gene was associated with multiple measures of height and lean body mass, as well as basal metabolic rate. This SNP also showed a validated association with brain malignancy and non-melanomatous skin cancer susceptibility, evidencing its role in differential cancer risk.
title: Heritable genetic variants in key cancer genes link cancer risk with anthropometric traits

finding: The germline variant rs61757955, located in the 3' UTR of GRB2, was identified as highly predictive of poor prognosis in low-grade glioma patients. It demonstrated a significant association with survival outcomes (p=7.08E-10, hazard ratio (HR)=20.4) and increased the area under the curve in survival models when included with eleven clinical covariates. Additionally, patients with this variant had a higher incidence of 1p/19q co-deletions and CIC mutations, both of which are significant in glioma pathogenesis.
title: The Germline Variants rs61757955 and rs34988193 are Predictive of Survival in Low Grade Glioma Patients

finding: The study by Li et al. (2018) identified polymorphism rs1052536 in a base excision repair gene as a risk factor for neural tube defects (NTDs) in a high-risk area of China. This finding was relevant in the context of altered folate levels affecting DNA repair mechanisms, specifically noting its association given the implications of KDM6A in DNA fragmentation repair. The increased incidence of NTDs highlights the significance of genetic factors in conjunction with environmental influences such as folate deficiency.
title: Folate deficiency facilitates coordination of KDM6A with p53 in response to DNA damage

finding: The SNP rs113994160 was associated with a pathogenic missense mutation (c.73C>T) in the HES7 gene, resulting in the HES7 R25W variant. This mutation was linked to segmentation defects of the vertebrae (SDV). In Axioloids derived from patient-like iPSC lines with this mutation, researchers noted increased axial elongation compared to healthy controls, loss of rostrocaudal patterning, and a loss of HES7 oscillation, which echoed findings from other genotypes, demonstrating the mutation's contribution to the pathogenesis of congenital spine diseases.
title: Reconstituting human somitogenesis in vitro

finding: The SNP rs936394 exhibited significant differences in binding between alleles in luciferase reporter assays, indicating a likely functional variant associated with SLE. It was identified as one of the top candidates among the regulatory SNPs evaluated in the study.
title: High-throughput identification of functional regulatory SNPs in systemic lupus erythematosus

finding: The SNP rs9907966 was shown to be among the candidates that displayed significant allele-specific regulation in the context of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), marking it as a likely functional non-coding variant.
title: High-throughput identification of functional regulatory SNPs in systemic lupus erythematosus

finding: In the context of BRCA1, the rs55851803 mutation introduced the pathogenic C64Y mutation, which was confirmed to disrupt E3 ubiquitin ligase activity. This finding was derived from a strong phenotypic signal in pooled screens, with a z-score of -6.57, and indicated substantial depletion over time.
title: Massively parallel assessment of human variants with base editor screens

finding: The SNP rs121918404 was identified as a well genotyped heterozygous variant with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.004% in the UK Biobank. It was noted for its high diagnostic accuracy compared to sequencing data.
title: Very rare pathogenic genetic variants detected by SNP-chips are usually false positives: implications for direct-to-consumer genetic testing

finding: The SNP rs4292 was found to be a putatively causal eSNP located in the ACE promoter, which was open across multiple cell types with the strongest peak in proximal tubules, consistent with its expression pattern.
title: Mapping genomic regulation of kidney disease and traits through high-resolution and interpretable eQTLs

finding: SNP rs370739771 showed significant associations with both CT and SA for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The findings demonstrated its involvement in cortical structural variations related to PTSD.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs7225002 was reported to have a discordant direction of effect with CT, while displaying a concordant direction with SA in relation to SCZ. This highlights complex relationships concerning this SNP's effect on brain structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs55938136 was associated with significant findings for both CT and SA in schizophrenia. Its HMPs for CT and SA were 3.28×10^-4 and 7.08×10^-5 respectively, common to variations in cortical structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs56305452 showed significant associations with greater CT in the inferior temporal cortex for ASD, indicating its genetic influence.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs7210219 was linked to increased thickness of the fusiform gyrus in ASD and PTSD, while showing discordance in SCZ, indicating a multifaceted genetic influence.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The lead variant rs28670687 was identified in association with type 1 diabetes (T1D), displaying a significant effect size (OR=1.42, 95% CI: 1.21-1.67) and a low BFDR (1.36%). This variant was notable for being in linkage disequilibrium with three 3'UTR variants, suggesting potential causality, although it did not meet the 1% BFDR threshold.
title: Enhanced genetic analysis of type 1 diabetes by selecting variants on both effect size and significance, and by integration with autoimmune thyroid disease

finding: The SNP rs58296998 was found to be associated with symptomatic cryptosporidiosis in children during the first year of life. Each additional T allele conferred 2.4 times the odds of developing the disease, indicating its significance in understanding genetic susceptibility in pediatric populations. Additionally, this SNP served as an eQTL for the PRKCA gene, suggesting a link between decreased expression of PRKCA and increased risk of infection.
title: Genome-wide association study of cryptosporidiosis in infants implicates PRKCA

finding: It had significant associations with T-helper cells and multiple other immune traits, highlighting its relevance in immune responses.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with multiple immune traits connected to T-cell responses.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP also showed significant associations associated with T-cell subsets, underlining its importance.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: The rs34579536 SNP was part of a set of variants in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with the H1/H2 haplotype at the KANSL1 locus. It was associated with an impact on KANSL1 protein function, indicating its potential role in PD risk. The identification of allele-specific expression (ASE) variation revealed that the risk-associated H1 allele correlated with lower KANSL1 expression.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The rs35833914 SNP was also identified within the high LD variants with the H1/H2 haplotype in KANSL1. Similar to rs34579536, this SNP was implicated in affecting KANSL1 protein function, thereby establishing a link to PD risk through a reduction in KANSL1 expression as observed in the allele-specific expression analysis.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The rs34043286 SNP was noted to be in high LD with the KANSL1 locus and was relevant to the functional assessment regarding PD. It contributed to the understanding that variations at this locus might influence KANSL1 expression and thereby PD susceptibility.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The rs12185268 SNP served as a tagging SNP within the KANSL1 gene that mediated allele-specific expression (ASE) in prior analyses, lending support to the theory that lower expression of KANSL1 is linked to heightened PD risk associated with the H1 haplotype.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The SNP rs1991556, associated with the MAPT locus, was identified as influential in analyzing forced vital capacity (FVC) effects on PD, indicating a potential bias due to its known association with PD.
title: The Parkinson’s Disease Mendelian Randomization Research Portal

finding: Located near the PECAM1 gene, this SNP showed associations driven by the binary traits involving coronary heart disease, reflecting high genetic correlations.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The rs3027172 SNP in the PER1 gene had an original finding related to its interaction with early life stress, which predicted problematic alcohol use. This suggests that genetic variations in circadian rhythm genes could influence addiction behaviors.
title: Circadian- and sex-dependent increases in intravenous cocaine self-administration in Npas2 mutant mice

finding: The study by Weber et al. (2016) revealed that carrying the CRHR1 minor rs17689918 allele increased the risk for panic disorders specifically in women. Furthermore, individuals with this allele exhibited heightened generalization of fear responses to safety cues, alongside increased activation in the amygdala and decreased activation in the frontal cortex during discriminative fear conditioning. This finding indicates that aberrations in corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF) signaling may contribute to an inability to appropriately regulate fear responses under perceived safe conditions, reflecting significant implications for understanding mood and anxiety disorders in females.
title: Sex differences in fear regulation and reward seeking behaviors in a fear-safety-reward discrimination task

finding: This SNP was associated with heel bone mineral density and was shown to be correlated with the expression of GAS72, with the strongest effect noted in cultured fibroblasts.
title: Genome-Wide Large-Scale Multi-Trait Analysis Characterizes Global Patterns of Pleiotropy and Unique Trait-Specific Variants

finding: The rs17681684 variant located in GLP2R was linked to increased risk of type 2 diabetes and associated with higher citrulline levels.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: The SNP rs78378222 showed evidence of association with both luminal A-like and triple-negative (TN) breast cancer subtypes, with opposite odds ratios indicating different effects on cancer risk depending on the subtype (OR=1.13 for luminal A-like vs 0.67 for TN). It was found to overlap with cell-type specific enhancers, being ACTIVE in basal cells, PRIMED in luminal progenitor cells, and OFF in mature luminal cells.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 32 novel breast cancer susceptibility loci from overall and subtype-specific analyses

finding: The SNP rs4566208 colocalised with an i-eQTL regulating a probable novel exon of ZSWIM7, with a high posterior colocalisation probability of 0.89. The GWAS p-value linked to this SNP was significant, indicating its importance in relation to Parkinson's disease.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: This lead signal at the HNF1B locus was associated primarily with islets, showing high probability assignment with a TOA of 0.72, indicating significant contribution to islet function.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs13342232 was identified as a risk variant for type 2 diabetes (T2D) that reduced the hepatic expression of SLC16A11 and affected the function of MCT11, a transporter associated with glucose metabolism. This disruption primarily impacted the low oxygen pericentral region of the liver, leading to metabolic changes consistent with T2D.
title: Mct11 deficiency alters hepatic glucose metabolism and energy homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs75493593 was also found to be a risk variant for type 2 diabetes (T2D), with similar effects on SLC16A11 liver expression and function as observed with rs13342232. The presence of T2D risk alleles at both SNPs led to alterations in hepatocyte glucose metabolism, resulting in a shift towards increased intracellular lactate and triacylglycerol accumulation.
title: Mct11 deficiency alters hepatic glucose metabolism and energy homeostasis

finding: This SNP was one of the trimodal QTLs identified in the GRB2 locus, indicating a significant effect on contact, accessibility, and gene expression, standing out in the analysis for its biological relevance.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: Also part of the best model found for GRB2, this variant worked in conjunction with rs12936583, contributing to the observed genetic effects on contact and expression.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: This trimodal QTL was associated with NCOR1 expression and encompassed a significant distance to modulate monocyte-related traits, hinting at its functional relevance in immunological contexts.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: The study demonstrated that the presence of the germline variant rs1058808 in the ERBB2 gene, which encodes the HER2 receptor, was associated with changes in the immune editing of breast tumors. It was found that individuals heterozygous for this SNP were less likely to develop HER2-positive breast cancer, implying that a high burden of germline-derived epitopes in ERBB2 acted to select against somatic gene amplification of this oncogene.
title: Germline-mediated immunoediting sculpts breast cancer subtypes and metastatic proclivity

finding: The variant rs1292053 located in the TUBD1 gene was similarly implicated in influencing somatic tumor evolution. The analysis highlighted that individuals with this variant exhibited an immune-mediated selection process where tumors preferentially amplified the allele associated with a weaker MHC class I epitope, thereby reducing the risk of developing aggressive forms of breast cancer.
title: Germline-mediated immunoediting sculpts breast cancer subtypes and metastatic proclivity

finding: The SNP rs1801690 was linked to creatine kinase levels as a cis pQTL for the gene APOH, indicating its significant influence on protein abundance.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: The SNP rs11658168 was identified as a trans eQTL encoding for TNNT2, a structural protein, thus correlating genetic variation with mRNA expression related to AF.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: SNP rs4292 was significantly associated with ACE expression in microdissected kidney tubule samples. The effect was enhanced by the allelic dosage, influencing the relationship between proximal tubule fractions and ACE expression, suggesting its critical role in kidney-related blood pressure regulation.
title: Mapping the genetic architecture of human traits to cell types in the kidney identifies mechanisms of disease and potential treatments

finding: The SNP rs8080306 was found within the transcription factor binding site (TFBS) of the promoter region of PRKAR1A and was identified as its eQTL. This finding suggests that rs8080306 is likely a causal variant regulating the expression of PRKAR1A. Since both FYN and PRKAR1A were correlated with AD pathways, this SNP was considered to be associated with AD through its regulatory role.
title: Genome-wide prediction and integrative functional characterization of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genes

finding: The SNP rs10512441, which is located 15 kb upstream of TMEM98, was associated with myopia in population studies. This variant is found in a region of active chromatin likely possessing regulatory functions, indicating its potential role in eye size regulation. Mutations in TMEM98 have been shown to cause dominant nanophthalmos, which correlates with the findings from the mouse model where loss of TMEM98 resulted in large, fragile eyes.
title: The nanophthalmos protein TMEM98 inhibits MYRF self-cleavage and is required for eye size specification

finding: The SNP rs17649553 was identified as disease-related, showing strong association with 11 nearby genes in DG-GCL, including 8 genes at p < 1e-20, and was also found to be FDR-significant in bulk hippocampus for 5 genes at p < 1e-20.
title: Cell type-specific genetic regulation of expression in the granule cell layer of the human dentate gyrus

finding: The study identified that the heterozygous expression of the SNP rs56014026 was characterized to maintain quiescent metabolism and goblet cell differentiation of colorectal cancer (CRC) cells. This SNP was expressed in low-grade colorectal carcinomas, indicating its potential role in regulating the metabolic pathways that influence tumor progression.
title: Colorectal cancer progression is potently reduced by a glucose-free, high-protein diet: comparison to anti-EGFR therapy

finding: This SNP was associated with multiple electrical physiology traits, including QRS duration, blood pressure, and cardiac anatomy. It also had eQTL associations with three genes in skeletal muscle, indicating its involvement in electrical conduction traits and overall cardiac function.
title: Genomic analysis reveals a functional role for myocardial trabeculae in adults

finding: The rs138213197 variant was recognized as a highly penetrant missense founder mutation in the HOXB13 gene and was significantly associated with PrCa, reflecting its historical relevance and extended haplotype effects.
title: Association Study of Over 200,000 Subjects Detects Novel Rare Variants, Functional Elements, and Polygenic Architecture of Prostate Cancer Susceptibility

finding: SNP rs9906189 (chr17:36549567 G/A) was strongly associated with the contribution to the overall promoter activity for both decomposed promoters of gene GGNBP2, with beta values of 0.222 and -0.222 for decomposed promoters 1 and 2, respectively. The associations were extremely significant, with FDR values of 2.05×10−26 and 2.05×10−25. Interestingly, this switch in decomposed promoter usage enhanced the effect of decomposed promoters on overall promoter activity, which was reflected in a limited prQTL beta of -0.063 with a non-significant FDR of 0.989.
title: Promoter sequence and architecture determine expression variability and confer robustness to genetic variants

finding: The RNF213 variant R4810K (rs112735431, c.14429G>A) was identified as a susceptibility variant for Moyamoya disease (MMD) in a genome-wide association study in 2011. This variant was particularly prevalent in East Asia and was associated with earlier onset and more severe deterioration of MMD. It was noted that heterozygous carriers had a higher risk of cerebral hemorrhage, while the homozygotic variant was more common in children with MMD. Findings from recent studies indicated that the R4810K variant led to impaired autophagy and endothelial cell dysfunction under oxygen-glucose deprivation conditions, which mimicked the ischemic environment present in MMD patients.
title: RNF213 variant and autophagic impairment: A pivotal link to endothelial dysfunction in Moyamoya disease

finding: The rs7209826 SNP was associated with increased estimated heel-bone BMD (eBMD), yielding an increase of 0.04 g/cm² per G allele (P=2.3×10^-36). This variant was implicated in a 57% lower risk of osteoporosis (OR 0.43; 95% CI 0.36-0.52; P=2.4×10^-18) and a 41% lower risk of sustaining a bone fracture (OR 0.59; 95% CI 0.54-0.66; P=1.4×10^-24). It was noted for its role in influencing sclerostin expression and consequently bone density.
title: Lifelong genetically lowered sclerostin and risk of cardiovascular disease

finding: The rs188810925 SNP was also associated with higher estimated heel-bone BMD of 0.07 g/cm² per A allele (P=1.3×10^-26). This variant contributed to a significantly lower risk of osteoporosis (OR 0.43; 95% CI 0.36-0.52; P=2.4×10^-18) and a distinct reduction in fracture risk (OR 0.59; 95% CI 0.54-0.66; P=1.4×10^-24). It similarly affected sclerostin levels related to bone health.
title: Lifelong genetically lowered sclerostin and risk of cardiovascular disease

finding: The rs7220711 SNP, which was selected as a proxy for rs7209826 due to high linkage disequilibrium, showed comparable effects on BMD measures, confirming its association with increased bone density. Although direct estimates for rs7220711 were not explicitly detailed in the context, it was functionally linked to SOST expression and acted consistently with the findings of rs7209826 in the examined cohorts.
title: Lifelong genetically lowered sclerostin and risk of cardiovascular disease

finding: Identified as a novel GWAS hit for CL with a P-imputed_1000G of 5.12×10^-6. It showed higher expression in CL biopsies.
title: A genome-wide association study highlights a regulatory role for IFNG-AS1 contributing to cutaneous leishmaniasis in Brazil

finding: The SNP rs62621376 on chromosome 17, located within the gene TTYH2, was linked to the occipital fusiform gyrus.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: The SNP rs11868358 located in a significant region on chromosome 17 overlapped with gene LRRC37A11P, associated with principal component PC1_GREY.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: This SNP had associations with balding patterns in European populations.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: The SNP rs1708618 was shown to regulate the expression of an FLCN isoform, indicating its importance in cardiac homeostasis, despite being a novel signal not previously tied to cardiac GWAS.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: In the analysis conducted by Lutkowska et al., it was found that the rs8067378 G/G genotype upregulated GSDMB1 expression in both non-cancerous and cancerous cervical tissues. However, the increased expression of the other three isoforms was limited to tumor tissue, indicating a differential regulatory effect of this SNP on GSDMB gene expression in varying tissue contexts.
title: Distinct GSDMB protein isoforms and protease cleavage processes differentially control pyroptotic cell death and mitochondrial damage in cancer cells

finding: Panganiban et al. reported that the rs11078928-C allele, which is associated with an increased risk for asthma, resulted in exon 6 skipping. This skipping prevented the translation of a crucial caspase-1 cleavage site at D236, leading to the production of pyroptosis-deficient GSDMB-NT in bronchial epithelial cells. This reveals how this SNP can affect GSDMB functionality in a specific cellular context.
title: Distinct GSDMB protein isoforms and protease cleavage processes differentially control pyroptotic cell death and mitochondrial damage in cancer cells

finding: The GLTPD2_rs536055318 (A263T) variant was identified as a rare missense variant significantly associated with lower levels of sphingomyelin (SM(d40:0), p=1.1E-12), which had not been previously studied in relation to genetic associations. This highlighted the variant's potential role in lipid metabolism.
title: Leveraging a founder population to identify novel rare-population genetic determinants of lipidome

finding: In the study, the rs242557 SNP was situated within an intronic cis-regulatory element (CRE) of the MAPT gene, specifically at the position 48,416 bp downstream of the MAPT promoter. This region was implicated in the regulation of MAPT expression since targeting it with CRISPR led to a significant reduction in MAPT’s expression by approximately 40%. Additionally, the presence of the H1c haplotype-tagging variant rs242557 was shown to influence MAPT gene expression and was previously associated with an increased risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD). Although the reference allele did not show a significant increase in luciferase activity in experiments, the alternate allele had been reported to enhance this activity. Thus, this SNP was confirmed as a functional element in regulating MAPT expression with possible implications for neurodegenerative disease risk.
title: MAPT expression is mediated by long-range interactions with cis-regulatory elements

finding: The SNP rs145766379 was identified as being located in the immediate vicinity of a rearrangement associated with Neurofibromatosis Type I. It was noted for its potential role in structural variation, as it extended regions of homology associated with inversions, indicating a possible mechanism for the gene fusion involving SUZ12P1-CRLF3.
title: Discovery of A Polymorphic Gene Fusion via Bottom-Up Chimeric RNA Prediction

finding: The SNP rs3169950 was discovered as a significant cis-eQTL for the target gene PSMB6 in gliomasphere cells, with a Bonferroni-adjusted p-value of 2.93 × 10^-12. The variant led to higher expression levels of PSMB6 in cells carrying the alternative allele (A) in comparison to the reference allele (G). This SNP is positioned near the transcription start site and may enhance the binding affinity of transcription factors like YY1, thus influencing the transcription level of PSMB6.
title: Discovering single-cell eQTLs from scRNA-seq data only

finding: The N498V mutation (rs146620441) was predicted by I-mutant 3.0 to have increased protein stability, contrasting with the other analyzed SNPs which exhibited decreased stability. This finding related to the impact of the SNP on the structural integrity of the STAT3 protein.
title: In Silico Genetics: Identification of pathogenic nsSNPs in human STAT3 gene associated with Job’s syndrome

finding: The R382W mutation (rs113994135) was found to be pathogenic and deleterious according to four different software tools. This mutation was previously documented in other studies, indicating its significance in the context of hyper-IgE syndrome and the structural modifications of STAT3.
title: In Silico Genetics: Identification of pathogenic nsSNPs in human STAT3 gene associated with Job’s syndrome

finding: The V637M mutation (rs113994139) was also identified as pathogenic, supporting findings from other literature. This mutation contributes to the overall understanding of STAT3's role in the immune regulation associated with hyper-IgE syndrome.
title: In Silico Genetics: Identification of pathogenic nsSNPs in human STAT3 gene associated with Job’s syndrome

finding: In the context of mood instability (MI), rs669915 was identified as a significant eQTL on chromosome 17q21, strongly associated with the expression of the pseudogene LRRC37A4P. This SNP also had implications for additional candidates like MAPT and CRHR1, highlighting its potential regulatory role in MI-related pathways.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: The SNP rs9909004 was suggestively associated (P=3.5×10^-4) with DCM and was noted for its association with the PRKCA gene, previously implicated in adverse left ventricular modeling.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: The SNP rs5848 was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease. This association was reported in the study by Sheng et al. (2014) and was further corroborated by Lee et al. (2011) in the Taiwanese population, indicating that this genetic variant in the progranulin gene contributes to the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease.
title: Granulins rescue inflammation, lysosome dysfunction, and neuropathology in a mouse model of progranulin deficiency

finding: The SNP rs2872507 was previously associated with reduced expression of GSDMB in intestinal biopsies from patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Its association with low expression of GSDMB highlighted its involvement in multiple phenotypes, including Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, and rheumatoid arthritis, demonstrating shared genetic effects among these conditions.
title: Mendelian Randomization integrating GWAS and eQTL data reveals genetic determinants of complex and clinical traits

finding: The SNP rs144216645 was found to have significant associations with both left-handed and right-handed versus non-right-handed phenotypes in the UK Biobank dataset. It was located within a large inversion haploblock and had p-values of 1.2E-09 for left-handedness and 2.3E-08 for right-handedness, underscoring its relevance to hand preference.
title: The molecular genetics of hand preference revisited

finding: The variant rs766783183 was initially found ranked at 172 when assessed solely on human phenotypic data related to Hypotrichosis 8, which is characterized by hair loss. However, when data from model organisms such as mice and fish were incorporated, the ranking of this variant dramatically improved to 8. This enhanced prioritization ultimately led to it being confirmed as the molecular diagnosis for Hypotrichosis 8, demonstrating the significance of including organism phenotype data in variant prioritization algorithms.
title: Towards a standard benchmark for variant and gene prioritisation algorithms: PhEval - Phenotypic inference Evaluation framework

finding: The SNP rs1108591 was observed to associate with EC4-specific peaks linked to the PECAM1 gene in the coverage plots. This finding indicated a potential role of this SNP in the mesenchymal population of endothelial cells relevant to atherosclerosis and CAD.
title: Single cell ‘omic profiles of human aortic endothelial cells in vitro and human atherosclerotic lesions ex vivo reveals heterogeneity of endothelial subtype and response to activating perturbations

finding: The signal led by rs59922886 colocalized strongly with a CTC1 eQTL in GTEx sun-exposed skin (PPH4 = 0.861) and also colocalized with an AURKB eQTL in eQTLGen (PPH4 = 0.919), leading to the attribution of this signal to CTC1.
title: Validation of human telomere length trans-ancestry meta-analysis association signals identifies POP5 and KBTBD6 as novel human telomere length regulation genes

finding: Noted for its association with breast cancer risk, particularly prominent in studies focusing on the effects of hormone therapy.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: The SNP rs4789774 was located adjacent to a differential methylation probe in <HEXDC>, which had not been previously associated with any psychiatric disorder. The DMP of <HEXDC> showed a modest negative correlation between its methylation status and the expression of <HEXDC>. This relationship suggests a regulatory role of rs4789774 on <HEXDC> gene expression, highlighting its potential relevance in the context of PTSD.
title: Meta-analysis of longitudinal epigenome-wide association studies of military cohorts reveals multiple CpG sites associated with post-traumatic stress disorder

finding: SNP rs62059712 was found within the ATP1B2 locus and was noteworthy for being associated with multiple gene promoters across both beta and alpha cell types. This finding demonstrates the variant's broad impact on gene regulation.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs2012 was associated with the thermotolerance of the apicomplexan-like microalga Chromera compared to traditional Symbiodiniaceae mutualists. The findings highlighted that Chromera exhibited greater temperature tolerance, which was crucial in understanding the molecular adaptation of corals to thermal stress.
title: Close relationship between coral-associated Chromera strains despite major differences within the Symbiodiniaceae

finding: The study indicated that the rs391300 G/A polymorphism in the serine racemase gene influenced the therapeutic efficacy of metformin in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. This finding highlighted the relevance of this SNP in the management of diabetic conditions, specifically in relation to retinal diabetic neuropathy and diabetic retinopathy.
title: Inhibition of serine racemase prevents diabetic retinopathy

finding: The SNP rs242557, located within a regulatory region of the MAPT intron 1, was strongly associated with PSP risk, particularly linked to the H1c sub-haplotype. It was reported to significantly increase MAPT expression and alter splicing in vitro, although results had conflicting replication in human brain tissue.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: The SNP rs8070723 was found to be a tag SNP for the H1/H2 haplotypes. In the analysis, it demonstrated an odds ratio of approximately 0.75 for the H2 haplotype's protective effect against PD, confirming its association with the risk for Parkinson's disease.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: This SNP was identified as the top SNP associated with PSP risk, showing a significant association (p = 2.39 x 10^-12, OR 1.44). It was in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs242557, reinforcing the association with the H1c haplotype and indicating its likely involvement in the regulation of MAPT and neighboring genes.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: It showed a strong association with PD in Stage 1 of the analysis with a p-value of 2.74 x 10^-9 and indicated its role in the H1 haplotype as a risk contributor with an odds ratio of approximately 1.22.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: This SNP was identified in the analysis of the H1 haplotypes and had an odds ratio of 1.21 (95% CI 1.10-1.32) for PD, although it failed to reach statistical significance in subsequent datasets.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: The SNP rs56014026 was identified as a heterozygous polymorphism in the P32/C1QBP/HABP1 gene. It was found to reduce mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation, specifically noted in the context of low-grade colorectal carcinomas. This finding is significant as it links the polymorphism to dysfunctional mitochondrial processes, which may have implications in tumor biology.
title: PA28γ promotes the malignant progression of tumor by elevating mitochondrial function via C1QBP

finding: The variant rs35897051 was found to be linked with Alzheimer's disease (AD) through its role in joint under-expressions in RNA and protein signals, supporting the idea that prioritized variants could significantly affect AD.
title: The functional impact of rare variation across the regulatory cascade

finding: The variant rs78378222, a rare germline variant located in the 3' UTR of the TP53 gene, demonstrated evidence supporting a new mechanism of cancer predisposition specifically in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. This finding indicated that alterations in the TP53 pathway can significantly contribute to cancer development, aligning with the broader theme of p53 oscillatory dysfunction due to genetic changes as discussed in the study.
title: Oncogenic alterations in the p53 pathway abolish oscillatory competence

finding: SNP rs9899649, found in the 17p11.2 genomic region, had been linked to amplitude traits associated with intrinsic brain activity, reflecting its potential role in influencing cognitive functions.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: The em-Var rs4790718 was prioritized over three linked GWAS SNPs related to SPAG7 and associated with platelet counts, demonstrating a significant finding in an LD block.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: This variant associated with cleft lip/palate demonstrated significant enhancer activity changes and was prioritized with the highest score.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs9914123 was shown to loop to the promoters of multiple genes, including <italic>SP2</italic>, <italic>PRR15L</italic>, <italic>CDK5RAP3</italic>, <italic>NFE2L1</italic>, <italic>CBX1</italic>, and <italic>HOXB3</italic>, and was associated with sleep regulation within an approximately 700 kb region.
title: Variant-to-gene-mapping followed by cross-species genetic screening identifies GPI-anchor biosynthesis as novel regulator of sleep

finding: The SNP rs11867934 was identified as the most significant retinopathy-associated eSNP from a set of 7,253 eSNPs tested, with a FDR of less than 0.05 and a meta-GWAS P value of 6.7×10^-6, which is below the Bonferroni adjusted p-value threshold of 6.9×10^-6. It was associated with <italic>FLCN</italic> gene expression in multiple tissues relevant to retinopathy, including artery and nerve. The presence of the minor allele was linked to an odds ratio of 0.86 (95% CI: 0.71, 1.00). The expression of <italic>FLCN</italic> was shown to be upregulated in the lymphoblastoid cell lines derived from individuals with diabetes in response to glucose, particularly more in individuals with diabetic retinopathy compared to those without, evidenced by a log fold change difference of 0.276 and a P value of 0.003.
title: Mendelian randomization identifies folliculin expression as a mediator of diabetic retinopathy

finding: In LNCaP cells, the risk allele of rs17765344 exhibited significantly higher transcriptional activity compared to the normal allele, showing a potential increase in gene expression.
title: A dinucleotide tag-based parallel reporter gene assay method

finding: In the context of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), rs1052553 was identified with a significant p-value of 0.007 in the original GWAS analysis. It overlapped a regulatory factor binding site and showed improved significance in validation studies with a p-value of 1.649e-15 compared to its discovery p-value of 8.156e-08.
title: fcfdr: an R package to leverage continuous and binary functional genomic data in GWAS

finding: This SNP was associated with cardiovascular diseases, indicating a significant genetic variant that may contribute to heart-related ailments.
title: Identification of biomarkers, pathways and potential therapeutic targets for heart failure using bioinformatics analysis

finding: The minor allele of rs56201815, a synonymous variant in ERN1, was associated with significantly increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and yielded the most robust meta-analysis p-value. Logistic regression indicated that this minor allele conferred a higher risk among APOE ε4 non-carriers, consistent across various cohorts.
title: Exome-wide age-of-onset analysis reveals exonic variants in ERN1, TACR3 and SPPL2C associated with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The missense variant rs12373123 in SPPL2C demonstrated protective effects against Alzheimer's disease. The minor allele was associated with decreased AD risk across several studies, particularly among APOE ε4 non-carriers, showing its potential roles in the pathology of multiple degenerative diseases.
title: Exome-wide age-of-onset analysis reveals exonic variants in ERN1, TACR3 and SPPL2C associated with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs62057153 was associated with SA1 and showed an extremely high level of significance (p=5.22×10−17 to 8.45×10−21). It is linked to the CRHR1 gene and identified as part of a cluster related to SA-derived GIBNs, highlighting its relevance to schizophrenia.
title: Genomic Structural Equation Modeling Reveals Latent Phenotypes in the Human Cortex with Distinct Genetic Architecture

finding: The locus rs9909861, linked with SA6, has been implicated in multiple traits including cognitive abilities, suggesting its importance in the genetic architecture of academic attainment.
title: Genomic Structural Equation Modeling Reveals Latent Phenotypes in the Human Cortex with Distinct Genetic Architecture

finding: The rs1126642 variant was found associated with the GFAP gene, which is important for astrocytic function, linked to white matter anomalies and conditions like Alexander disease.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The SNP rs1625895, located in the TP53 gene, was associated with an increased risk of sarcopenic obesity in Iranian older adults, indicating a potential link between this polymorphism and metabolic disorders that could relate to pathways involved in type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM).
title: Bioinformatics Analysis of next generation sequencing data for Risk Prediction in Patients with Type 1 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SNP rs7207400 was identified as independent and significant within the same genomic locus as rs534115641, predominantly linked to traits related to Alzheimer's disease. It was involved in associations with several neuropsychiatric traits.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs199499 was also linked as an independent signal within the locus associated with GM-BAG, identifying significant connections with Alzheimer's disease and mental health disorders.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs9303521 was connected to GM-BAG, where it was specifically associated with depressed affect, highlighting its relevance in neuropsychiatric disorders.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs7225384 was identified within the GM-BAG locus, related to traits encompassing depression and other mental health issues.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs2331413 was identified to be located near the ERN1 gene, which is known for its role as a sensor of unfolded proteins within the endoplasmic reticulum, triggering the unfolded protein response signaling pathway. This SNP was associated with three downstream genes that are also proteins of the endoplasmic reticulum. The ERN1 locus had been previously associated with drug-induced hepatotoxicity in GWAS studies, providing a biological context for its significance.
title: DataRemix: a universal data transformation for optimal inference from gene expression datasets

finding: The SNP rs8081059 was associated with an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma, indicating a potential deleterious effect of this variant on cancer risk.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphisms and Zn transport by nuclear ZIP11 shape cancer phenotypes in HeLa cells

finding: The SNP rs11871756 was linked to bladder cancer risk, suggesting that this variant may contribute to the development of this cancer type.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphisms and Zn transport by nuclear ZIP11 shape cancer phenotypes in HeLa cells

finding: The SNP rs11077654 was also associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, further implicating ZIP11 genetic variants in promoting carcinogenic processes.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphisms and Zn transport by nuclear ZIP11 shape cancer phenotypes in HeLa cells

finding: The SNP rs9913017 was identified as being connected to bladder cancer risk, reinforcing the role of ZIP11 variants in cancer susceptibility.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphisms and Zn transport by nuclear ZIP11 shape cancer phenotypes in HeLa cells

finding: The SNP rs4969054 demonstrated an association with bladder cancer risk, adding to the evidence that ZIP11 polymorphisms can influence cancer outcomes.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphisms and Zn transport by nuclear ZIP11 shape cancer phenotypes in HeLa cells

finding: The SNP rs9898988, located on chromosome 17, was identified as a second top SNP for CCDC106, being an intronic variant of the SKAP1 gene. This SNP had previously been linked to overall epithelial ovarian cancer and HGSOC.
title: Cis- and trans-eQTL TWAS of breast and ovarian cancer identify more than 100 risk associated genes in the BCAC and OCAC consortia

finding: The SNP rs2229304 was identified as the top eQTL predictor for MLLT10P1, a gene that showed validation in independent GWAS summary statistics for overall ovarian cancer risk, suggesting its role as a candidate susceptibility locus.
title: Cis- and trans-eQTL TWAS of breast and ovarian cancer identify more than 100 risk associated genes in the BCAC and OCAC consortia

finding: The polymorphism rs5848 in the Progranulin gene correlated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) as reported by Sheng et al. in 2014. This finding suggested genetic susceptibility to AD linked to Progranulin, a key player in neuroinflammation and microglial function, supporting the overarching theme of altered mechanisms in the pathology of AD.
title: Microglial amyloid beta clearance is driven by PIEZO1 channels

finding: The analysis revealed that the RedPenMC carrier had the C/C genotype for rs5848, a <italic>GRN</italic> 3’ UTR variant, which is a less efficient binding site for miR-659 compared to the T allele. This finding suggested that the C allele contributed to higher <italic>GRN</italic> expression in RedPenMC, providing insights into the mechanisms that may protect against frontotemporal dementia (FTD).
title: Single-cell multimodal omics and directly reprogrammed neurons to probe reduced penetrance in Frontotemporal Dementia

finding: Sanger sequencing confirmed the presence of the T>G substitution (c.882T>G) at g.42428777T>G for rs794729670, a mutation in the <italic>GRN</italic> gene (p.Tyr294*). This finding related to the pathogenic variant directly associated with FTD, underlining its relevance in understanding genetic factors in disease manifestation.
title: Single-cell multimodal omics and directly reprogrammed neurons to probe reduced penetrance in Frontotemporal Dementia

finding: The ITGB4 intronic SNP (rs9890231) showed significant association with Aβ40_TBS, influencing splicing of the ITGB4 gene, indicating potential functional consequences.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The SNP rs7210937 was found within the seed sequence of a microRNA, showing evidence of population differentiation with a notably high Fst value between African and European populations. It demonstrated that in European populations, the ancestral form of miR-1269b was prevalent, while in African populations, the derived version was more common, indicating that allele frequency shifts could affect novel target sites linked to this microRNA.
title: Pervasive selection against microRNA target sites in human populations

finding: The SNP rs9889296 was found 75.9kb from CCL8 and was implicated as an eQTL through fine mapping. This highlighted its relevance to gene expression in the context of psoriasis.
title: T cells promote distinct transcriptional programs of cutaneous inflammatory disease in human skin structural cells

finding: The rs78761021 SNP at the GLP2R locus was previously reported and showed a high linkage (0.87) to the citrulline association described with rs17681684. It supports significant findings related to type 2 diabetes risk and metabolic regulation.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: The research indicated that the rs2070935 polymorphism significantly influenced GFAP expression levels in astrocytomas, depending on the tumor grade. This finding was crucial as it linked genetic variation to the astrocytic response observed in tumors, particularly highlighting how upregulation of GFAP isoforms corresponded with the histological features of Pilocytic Astrocytomas (PA) and the aggressive gliosis observed in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). The context of this finding related to the understanding of tumor biology and potential therapeutic implications.
title: Aquaporin-4 expression levels and mis-localization are inversely linked to peritumoral edema in gliomas of varying aggressiveness

finding: This SNP was a lead SNP for Alzheimer's disease (AD) showing a genome-wide significant association (P=6e-09) in the context of 4-subjects. While it did not reach genome-wide significance for POAG (P=1.2e-06), it was highly correlated with the POAG lead SNP (rs242559) with an LD r² of 0.89.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: Identified as the most significant SNP for POAG, located within an intron of the MAPT gene. It has associations with retinal GCIPL and RNFL thickness, which were linked to increased cognitive decline.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The haplotype rs1800547 in MAPT was identified as a genetic variant of interest connected to the risk of Parkinson's Disease (PD), playing a role in the overall risk assessment of the iPSC lines studied.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: The SNP rs8070070 was associated with GM-CSF positive CD4 T cells, which are implicated in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases, particularly Multiple Sclerosis. This association suggested that genetic variations at this locus might influence the regulation of T cell responses in autoimmune conditions, providing insights into potential therapeutic targets.
title: Gene regulatory network of human GM-CSF secreting T helper cells

finding: The rare variant rs77542162 was found to be associated with blood lipid levels in the Dutch population. This finding highlighted the importance of population-specific reference panels, demonstrating how such resources can lead to discoveries of trait-associated variants that might not be identified using more generalized panels.
title: NyuWa Genome Resource: Deep Whole Genome Sequencing Based Chinese Population Variation Profile and Reference Panel

finding: The study linked the SNP rs62088464 to the GATA3 transcription factor and its regulatory activity. This SNP was identified within a GATA motif sequence in a peak associated with GATA3, where the risk allele was associated with decreased pulmonary function, particularly linked to conditions like pulmonary fibrosis and inflammatory lung diseases influenced by Th2 immune responses. In the context of cell expression, it was found that GATA3 significantly binds to the risk allele, enhancing the regulatory activity related to the expression of the TSEN54 gene, which is notably enriched in sputum from patients experiencing type-2 airway inflammation.
title: NEAT-seq: Simultaneous profiling of intra-nuclear proteins, chromatin accessibility, and gene expression in single cells

finding: The SNP rs1859962 was also confirmed as a positive original finding, linked to T2E with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.52 and a p-value of 5.05 x 10^-3.
title: Germline determinants of the prostate tumor genome

finding: The rs2750012 polymorphism in GLOD4 was associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) in the Arab population of northern Israel. This association was robust, having been replicated in a meta-analysis involving seven independent genome-wide association studies (GWAS) datasets, indicating a significant role for GLOD4 in the context of AD.
title: Association of GLOD4 with Alzheimer’s Disease in Humans and Mice

finding: In the context of the IAV experiment, rs11867191 demonstrated cell-type-specific effects, although interaction effects across cell types did not show significant differences.
title: Modeling heterogeneity in single-cell perturbation states enhances detection of response eQTLs

finding: This variant influenced the CCR7 gene, showing significant upregulation and suggesting a role as a gatekeeper variant modulating lymphocyte and eosinophil counts.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: The variant rs2269907 was found to increase expression and was located in an active candidate enhancer region. It corrected a mismatch in the JunD transcription factor motif, likely improving JunD binding and promoting gene expression.
title: Deciphering regulatory DNA sequences and noncoding genetic variants using neural network models of massively parallel reporter assays

finding: The study identified that the alternative allele at rs150929926 resulted in a Q130R mutation in NLRP1, and this mutation was significant because it eliminated the susceptibility of NLRP1 to cleavage by the CVB3 3C pro protease. The investigation indicated that this mutation was present in more than 1 in every 1000 African alleles, and when the Q130R mutation was introduced into NLRP1, it led to a loss of inflammasome activation in response to the 3C pro cleaving activity. This finding emphasized the role of specific genetic variations in influencing host susceptibility and immune responses to viral proteases.
title: Diverse viral proteases activate the NLRP1 inflammasome

finding: The study found that the vitamin D effect in the VDAART trial was significantly influenced by genotype, with the GG genotype exhibiting a protective effect on asthma risk in children, while CC or GC genotypes did not respond to vitamin D. This finding was specifically related to sphingolipid production.
title: Vitamin D constrains inflammation by modulating the expression of key genes on Chr17q12-21.1

finding: Similar to rs12936231, rs4065275 was shown to be functionally relevant to asthma and was in high linkage disequilibrium with other SNPs that affect the transcription of ORMDL3, which is associated with asthma risk.
title: Vitamin D constrains inflammation by modulating the expression of key genes on Chr17q12-21.1

finding: The rs1042522 mutation was located in the coding region of the TP53 gene and was identified as a known high-risk mutation associated with multiple tumorigenesis cases. The analysis revealed that this mutation was present in the HepG2 hepatoma cell line, but absent in normal liver cells (HL7702). Additionally, the mutation was found in the cervical cancer cell lines HeLa (HPV18-positive) and C-33a (HPV-negative), indicating a potential link between the TP53 mutation and carcinogenesis, particularly in the context of HPV infection.
title: CRISPR-assisted targeted enrichment-sequencing (CATE-seq)

finding: The SNP rs7212349 was identified as the top associated variant for the gene SARM1, showing a significant association with age-related macular degeneration (AMD) with a p-value of 1.8e-7 in GWAS data. Although it did not reach the conventional genome-wide significance threshold, its eQTL p-value was remarkably low at 1.0e-22, indicating an important role in AMD pathogenesis through the modulation of SARM1 expression.
title: Towards the identification of causal genes for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs78378222, located in the TP53 locus, was associated with melanoma and lymphocytic leukemia. This finding highlighted the role of TP53 in the genetic architecture of cancer susceptibility, illustrating its involvement in multiple cancer types.
title: Pan-Cancer Study Detects Novel Genetic Risk Variants and Shared Genetic Basis in Two Large Cohorts

finding: The rs11867855 SNP within the SHMT1 gene was significantly linked to increased appendicular lean mass, achieving genome-wide significance (p=2.9e-9, beta=0.0132) in the UK Biobank study, highlighting its relevance in muscle mass dynamics.
title: Skeletal muscle hypertrophy rewires glucose metabolism: an experimental investigation and systematic review

finding: The study found that the rs5918 single nucleotide variant (SNV) in human β3 integrin was associated with ANDV infection susceptibility in a Chilean population. The TT genotype, coding for leucine, was present in 89.2% of ANDV cases and 60% of exposed close-household contacts who remained uninfected, indicating a significant risk factor (OR between 6.2 to 12.6, p<0.05). In contrast, the protective CC genotype (coding for proline) was absent in all ANDV cases but found in 11.4% of uninfected close-household contacts. Hence, rs5918 TT variant indicated a higher predisposition to ANDV infection.
title: Single nucleotide variant at the αvβ3 integrin associated to Andes virus infection susceptibility

finding: SNP rs2291725 led to an S>G amino acid exchange in the Gastric Inhibitory Polypeptide (GIP), associated with body fat traits, coronary artery disease, and diabetes. The variant peptide was detected in carriers and provided evidence for a causal role in these phenotypes. This SNP had not been previously reported by affinity proteomics.
title: Nanoparticle Enrichment Mass-Spectrometry Proteomics Identifies Protein Altering Variants for Precise pQTL Mapping

finding: The SNP rs563336550 was identified as a novel splice donor variant associated with the GRN gene. It had a minor allele count of 4 and a significantly increased frequency in the MANOLIS cohort compared to other populations. This variant contributed to a rare variant pQTL for GRN, which was one of the six study-wide significant associations regarding serum protein biomarker levels.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: The rs5848 polymorphism was associated with a reduction in plasma and brain levels of granulin in Alzheimer's disease patients, which highlighted a significant role for this SNP in the pathophysiology of AD. Moreover, studies indicated that rs5848 was linked to an increased risk of developing Alzheimer's disease, showcasing its relevance in studying both genetic predisposition and the mechanisms of amyloid-related pathology.
title: A multifaceted role of progranulin in regulating amyloid-beta dynamics and responses

finding: The rs25531 SNP was linked to neuroticism through its association with the resting state functional connectivity of the amygdala and fusiform gyrus. This finding was derived from research that highlighted the role of this SNP in contributing to the neurobiological underpinnings of major depressive disorder (MDD), showcasing its relevance to the disorder's clinical symptoms.
title: Contrastive Functional Connectivity Defines Neurophysiology-informed Symptom Dimensions in Major Depression

finding: The study identified a natural variant in the C-C motif chemokine 14 proteoform related to the SNP rs16971802 (K61E). This variant distinguished differences in proteoform expression among plasma donors. Specifically, the wild type (WT, PFR 98045) was detected in all three tested donors, while the K61E variant (PFR 98050) showed varying levels of expression among donors. The results indicated significant fold-changes in ratios between the WT and K61E variants, with p-values less than 2e-5, suggesting a notable impact of the mutation on proteoform levels and potential implications for precision medicine in immunology.
title: Deep Profiling of Plasma Proteoforms with Engineered Nanoparticles for Top-down Proteomics

finding: This SNP was associated with multiple phenotypes: it showed strong links to total surface area (SA) with a significant P-value of 2.3 x 10^-32 and was replicated with a P-value of 3.5 x 10^-43. Additionally, it was identified in the 17q21.31 inversion region and associated with Parkinson's disease, educational attainment, and neuroticism.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: The SNP rs224534 was identified through the Coupled Mixed Model (CMM) method as being associated with both Alzheimer's disease (AD) and substance use disorder (SUD). This SNP resides in the TRPV1 gene, which encodes a protein involved in sensory signaling. Previous studies suggested that positive modulation of TRPV1 channels may offer therapeutic targets for mitigating Alzheimer's disease, highlighting its significant role in this neurological condition. Additionally, research indicated that TRPV1 has a critical function in morphine addiction, and other studies demonstrated that the deletion of TRPV1 in animal models altered the effects of ethanol, establishing a link between TRPV1 and alcoholism.
title: Coupled Mixed Model for Joint Genetic Analysis of Complex Disorders with Two Independently Collected Data Sets

finding: The SNP rs1136287 (gene SERPINF1) showed an association with increased disease-related mortality (DRM) (HR=2.32, P=0.008) in patients with HLA-C*03:04. This suggested that carriers of this mHA faced higher risks of death related to their disease following alloHCT.
title: Associations of Minor Histocompatibility Antigens with Clinical Outcomes Following Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

finding: The SNP TP53 rs1042522 had a significant interaction with NSAID use. GG homozygotes for this SNP experienced a decreased risk of CRC when using NSAIDs, while C-allele carriers showed increased risk with NSAID use, replicating earlier findings.
title: Intake of red and processed meat, use of non-steroid anti inflammatory drugs, genetic variants and risk of colorectal cancer; a prospective study of the Danish “Diet, Cancer and Health” cohort

finding: The study found that treatment with veliparib in a patient with a deleterious germline BRCA1 mutation (c.4611_4612insG; p.Gln1538Alafs, rs80357915) resulted in marked changes in the immune contexture of tumors. Specifically, there was a 25% increase in CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, a 75% increase in CD20+ B-lymphocytes, and a 33% reduction in CD4+ helper T cells after long-term veliparib treatment. This indicated that veliparib had a significant immunomodulatory effect on BRCA1 deficient tumors, enhancing anti-tumor responses in advanced TNBC. The finding related directly to the patient's genetic background, highlighting the relevance of the BRCA1 mutation in response to PARP inhibition and consequent immune modulation.
title: Chromatin-Bound PARP1 Correlates with Upregulation of Inflammatory Genes in Response to Long-Term Treatment with Veliparib

finding: The findings showed an association between rs3091316 and CCL chemokine expression, relevant to around 100-fold variability in gene expression among individuals involved in ongoing inflammatory responses.
title: The association between transcriptional regulation of macrophage differentiation and activation and genetic susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease

finding: The SNP rs535861886 was identified in patient 103, where it affected the binding site occupied by the transcription factor EGR2. This finding was relevant to the understanding of gene regulatory modules (GRM) influencing the phenotype in patients with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), a condition that manifests with severe inflammatory and autoimmune symptoms.
title: Decoding mutational hotspots in human disease through the gene modules governing thymic regulatory T cells

finding: The SNP rs74639548 was found in patient 113 and similarly impacted the binding site for the transcription factor EGR2. This result contributed to the exploration of the gene regulatory modules that govern the Treg signature in CVID patients, supporting the notion of shared genetic interactions in polygenic disorders.
title: Decoding mutational hotspots in human disease through the gene modules governing thymic regulatory T cells

finding: The SNP rs11080327 was identified as an expression SNP (eSNP) for the gene SLFN5, indicating a significant relationship between the genotype at this SNP and the expression levels of the SLFN5 gene. Additionally, it was characterized as a causal SNP (cSNP) for a chromatin peak located in the first intron of SLFN5. This discovery occurred while conducting mediation analysis in genetic mapping studies, which highlighted the importance of considering measurement error in interpreting such findings.
title: The Trouble with Triples: Examining the Impact of Measurement Error in Mediation Analysis

finding: The common rs5918 polymorphism in the ITGB3 gene was associated with the risk of coronary artery disease and emphasized the genetic predisposition to vascular complications that may accompany GDM.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and signaling pathways in gestational diabetes mellitus by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The rs6505162 C>A polymorphism in the <italic>miRNA-423</italic> gene was identified as having a protective association against the occurrence of coronary artery aneurysm (CAA) and coronary artery lesion (CAL) in Kawasaki disease (KD) patients among southern Chinese. Specifically, the CA/AA genotypes were associated with a reduced risk of CAA (Adjusted OR=1.30, 95% CI=1.02-1.67, P=0.037) and CAL (Adjusted OR=1.56, 95% CI=1.19-2.03, P=0.001), despite not showing a direct relationship with KD susceptibility overall.
title: The rs6505162 C>A polymorphism in the miRNA-423 gene exhibits a protective element of coronary artery in a southern Chinese population with Kawasaki disease

finding: The study identified rs6503650 in the JUP gene as a significant methylation quantitative trait locus (methQTL) regulating the methylation levels of all 14 hub CpG sites in the brown module. This SNP was related to T2DM risk and played a key role in regulating genes contributing to insulin signaling and glucose uptake in adipocytes, with implications for the regulation of glucose sensitivity. The findings suggested that the JUP gene, via rs6503650, was critical in the functional network correlating with T2DM risk factors such as insulin and C-peptide levels.
title: Network analysis after epigenome wide methylation study revealed JUP as a regulator of co-methylated risk-module for T2DM

finding: The rs538628 variant was associated with left-handedness and was located in the 17q21.31 locus, which has known associations with intellectual disability and schizophrenia.
title: RSGenome-wide association study identifies 49 common genetic variants associated with handedness

finding: The MAPT haplotype variant rs180054 was explored within the genetic landscape of the iPSC lines and highlighted as being associated with Parkinson's disease (PD) risk.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: The variant p.P72R associated with the SNP rs1042522 had been confirmed as somatic in multiple tumor types, including a GBM case in COSMIC. This variant resulted in decreased inhibition of PGC-1α, which is pivotal in mitochondrial biogenesis and oxidative phosphorylation. Consequently, tumor cells expressing the p.P72R variant showed enhanced migration and invasion due to improved mitochondrial function. Additionally, the p.P72R mutation in p53 was found to have increased affinity for binding p73, leading to reduced p73-induced apoptosis. In the analyzed samples, all cells exhibited this variant with the implication of homozygosity, although previous data indicated loss of heterozygosity favoring the p.P72R in GBM patients.
title: Scalable co-sequencing of RNA and DNA from individual nuclei

finding: This SNP was the lead stress-interactive eQTL for the HSF5 eGene in the dACC, falling in an NFkB binding motif. It demonstrated that stress encoding through this SNP could modify gene expression specifically in the context of stress.
title: Common genetic variation impacts stress response in the brain

finding: Identified as the leading stress-interactive eQTL for the STX8 eGene in the BLA, rs62063655 was positioned in a GR binding motif in iGABA open chromatin, suggesting its role in modulating gene response to stress.
title: Common genetic variation impacts stress response in the brain

finding: The SNP rs4790904 was associated with Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in a study involving U.S. Caucasian and African-American veterans. The association indicated that variation at this locus could contribute to the genetic risk for PTSD, highlighting its relevance in understanding the disorder's heritability and underlying genetic mechanisms.
title: Analysis of Genetically Regulated Gene Expression identifies a trauma type specific PTSD gene, SNRNP35

finding: The study identified a germline mutation in the TP53 gene, specifically TP53:c.395A>T, p.Lys132Met, associated with Li-Fraumeni Syndrome in the primary medulloblastoma sample (LFS_MB_P). This mutation was confirmed through variant calling in both the primary tumor and the paired blood control sample, indicating somatic inactivation of the wild-type TP53 allele through deletion in the tumor samples.
title: Long-read sequencing of diagnosis and post-therapy medulloblastoma reveals complex rearrangement patterns and epigenetic signatures

finding: At the MAPT locus (rs4792897), linked to neurodegenerative diseases, the SNP showed strong selection signals, highlighting genetic adaptations in response to evolving health challenges over time.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The IKZF3 rs12946510 genetic variant exhibited an association with multiple sclerosis (MS) onset and severity in a Serbian patient group.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The CCL5 rs2107538 variant was reported to be associated with multiple sclerosis (MS) in a study conducted among patients.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The CCL2 rs3760396 variant was demonstrated to be associated with the risk of multiple sclerosis (MS) based on previous findings.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The variant rs56340929 in the ARHGAP44 gene was significantly associated with changes in glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), explaining nearly 30% of the linkage peak observed in a longitudinal study of non-diabetic Europeans. This variant's association was supported by RNAseq data, which significantly linked ARHGAP44 expression with changes in HbA1c.
title: A Novel Gene ARHGAP44 for Longitudinal Changes in Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) in Subjects without Type 2 Diabetes: Evidence from the Long Life Family Study (LLFS) and the Framingham Offspring Study (FOS)

finding: The C allele at rs921649 was identified as a risk variant associated with increased susceptibility to autoimmune diseases, including type 1 diabetes (T1D). The C allele was particularly noted for its role in the complex interaction of genetic predisposition affecting lymphocyte function, contrasting with its protective role against asthma.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: SNP rs35203463 was identified as a cis-pQTL for GRN, which was shown to be significant in MR analyses. Silencing GRN expression led to decreased platelet counts, suggesting a novel connection between GRN regulation, platelet production, and cardiovascular disease outcomes.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits

finding: Similar to rs35203463, SNP rs850733 acted as a cis-pQTL for GRN. The findings from the siRNA gene knockdown experiments indicated that silencing GRN resulted in decreased PLT, further supporting the role of this SNP in the relationship between GRN and platelet counts linked to cardiovascular risk.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits
